1.name: Miyama Town
1.content:
Miyama Town (Ê∑±Â±±Áî∫, Miyama-ch≈ç?) is the suburban area of Fuyuki that contains old houses and traditional buildings. It can be split into two main parts, the traditional Japanese houses district and the foreigners' houses district.[3] The road to Homurahara Academy, where the protagonist studies, is set between the two districts.

The intersection road connects to the shopping street, the school, the northern and southern parts of town, and to the bridge.

The Matou and Tohsaka residences are located in the foreigners' district, while Shirou's and the Fujimuras' houses are in the traditional district.

There is a shopping district somewhere in Miyama, apparently pretty close to Shirou Emiya's place as he walks to and from there to do his everyday shopping.

Emiya residence
Tohsaka residence
Matou residence

Mackenzie residence
The Mackenzie residence is the house owned by Glen and Martha Mackenzie, located on a hill in Miyama.

Waver Velvet, needing to use a fake identity to cover himself in the Fourth Holy Grail War, sought out the couple after learning they lived alone in order to also avoid having to spend money on a hotel. Getting information on them through hypnosis, he deceived them with suggestion Magecraft into making them believe he is their grandson, "Waver Mackenzie", through transfiguring their own impression of their grandson onto his own image. He made them believe that he was visiting while studying abroad in England.

Homurahara Academy

Mount Miyama
Mount Miyama („Éû„Ç¶„É≥„ÉàÊ∑±Â±±, Maunto Miyama?) is the shopping district in Miyama Town.

Koushuuensaikan Taizan (Á¥ÖÊ¥≤ÂÆ¥Ê≠≥È§®„ÉªÊ≥∞Â±±, K≈çsh≈´ensaikan Taizan?) is the only Chinese restaurant in Miyama Town. It is operated by the manager Batsu, renowned for having extremely spicy food. Kirei Kotomine frequents the restaurant for mapo tofu.[7]
Edomaeya - A food stand in Miyama Town. Sells taiyaki for 80 yen each. On the other hand, the stores in Verde have a better selection. Popular among the students.[8]
Singing Birds Retreat (Ë©†È≥•Â∫µ, Eich≈ç Iori?) - The antique store where Rider works.[9]
Flower Shop - One of the many places where Lancer works.
Riverside park (Êµ∑ÊµúÂÖ¨Âúí, Kaihin k≈çen?) is located by the bridge.

2.name: The Tohsaka family
2.content:
The Tohsaka family, with a lineage spanning 200 years, has a fascinating history as Hidden Christians in Japan. Despite their humble beginnings, they have risen through the ranks to become one of the most influential Mage families. Under the leadership of their head, Nagato Tohsaka, they have honed their skills in Jewel Magecraft and even incorporated a secret Chinese Kenpo martial arts style into their practice. Their connections with the Mage's Association and the Holy Church have further bolstered their standing.

Intriguingly, it is believed that the Tohsaka family acquired knowledge from the Edelfelts, particularly in the areas of Jewel Magecraft and Gandr usage. Whether this was through marriage or theft of magical abilities remains uncertain. Nevertheless, it has undoubtedly contributed to their mastery of these arcane arts.

During the development of the Heaven's Feel ritual, Nagato's daughter played a significant role in its completion, surpassing even her father's contributions. The Tohsaka's duty in this ritual is to provide their Spiritual Land for its execution.

In alternate universes such as Apocrypha and EXTRA, the Tohsaka family takes different paths. In Apocrypha, they abandon their pursuit of the Holy Grail and seek alternative methods to reach the Root in Fuyuki. In EXTRA, tragedy befalls them, resulting in their near destruction in the 1990s.

The Tohsaka family's rich history and diverse pursuits make them an intriguing and influential force within the world of Magecraft.

3.name: The Einzbern family
3.content:
The Einzbern family is an ancient magus lineage located in Germany, near the Rhine River. They were created by the disciples of a powerful magician who sought to replicate their master's achievements in the Third Magic. The family possesses the Das Rheingold, a treasure obtained by Siegfried after slaying the dragon Fafnir. With their knowledge of the gold, they can create vessels for the Holy Grail.

Around 1,000 years ago, the Einzberns embarked on a quest to recover their lost miracle but realized they needed outside assistance. This led them to establish the Heaven's Feel ritual 200 years ago with the help of the Makiri and Tohsaka families. They built the Great Grail of Fuyuki and were responsible for creating a new vessel for each Grail War.

Over time, most human mages left the Einzbern family, leaving only Jubstacheit von Einzbern and his Tuners. Jubstacheit has been producing Justeaze-model homunculi to collect data on the Third Magic. In past Holy Grail Wars, the Einzbern Masters were often eliminated early due to their specialization in alchemy rather than battle. However, for the Fourth Heaven's Feel, they hired Kiritsugu Emiya as an outsider and gave him a catalyst to summon King Arthur. Unfortunately, Kiritsugu betrayed them and destroyed the Holy Grail.

The Einzberns' homeland is constantly in winter, possibly artificially maintained. The family is not accustomed to heat and prefers conducting Holy Grail Wars during winter. They do not cultivate flowers due to their snowy mountain dwelling, but they have a brewery for producing alcohol necessary for their Magecraft. The Einzberns have a limited understanding of Japanese culture and maintain a close relationship with Darjeeling tea from the Talbot farm.

In the world of "Apocrypha," the Einzberns remain determined to reproduce the Third Magic despite the Greater Grail being stolen. They continue to have relationships with other magi and are struggling to create a new Greater Grail. Their Thaumaturgical Attribute is focused on the flow and transfer of power, allowing them to specialize in Alchemy, particularly in creating homunculi. The Einzbern homunculi are designed with specific functions and even discarded ones are stronger than the average magus. Their Magecraft revolves around the creation and refinement of substances, specifically precious metals, with a focus on structural manipulation.

4.name: The Matou family
4.content:
The Matou family, formerly known as the Makiri family, is a long-standing magus lineage in Fuyuki City, Japan. Originally from Russia, they sought refuge in Japan and changed their name to Matou. However, over the past 200 years, they have experienced a decline in their magical abilities, with many of their descendants losing their capacity to manifest Magic Circuits. The true reason behind this decline remains unclear.

Their last remaining heir, Shinji Matou, has no Magic Circuits at all. The practice of passing down their Magic Crest among family members ceased generations ago. With no other options to continue their bloodline, the Matou family began taking in pupils from other families. However, due to their prideful nature and questionable practices, no one willingly seeks out their mentorship. In a bid to secure an heir, Zouken Matou approached the Tohsaka family and adopted Sakura Tohsaka into the Matou lineage.

The Magecraft of the Matou family revolves around the concept of "absorbing" or binding something to oneself. Their teaching method involves physically carving magecraft knowledge into the body using Crest Worms. This torturous process allows the body itself to learn magecraft rather than relying on intellectual understanding. While efficient, it is a horrifying practice that Rin Tohsaka states could yield even greater power than her own magecraft abilities within a few months.

The Matou family has made significant contributions to Thaumaturgy research and played a role in establishing the Servant system of Heaven's Feel and creating Command Spells for Masters. Despite these accomplishments, in Fate/Apocrypha's world, the Matou family lacks a successor and thus faces a future without magi.

5.name: Servants
5.content: Servants are powerful beings known as Ghost Liners that are bound to Masters. They can be Heroic Spirits, Divine Spirits, Phantoms, Wraiths, or even living people. Unlike regular familiars, Heroic Spirits are incredibly strong and cannot be contracted by most magi. The Holy Grail is unable to summon a true Heroic Spirit, so vessels are prepared beforehand to facilitate the summoning process. These vessels, called Classes, act as temporary names and methods of existing for the Heroic Spirits. The Command Spells are used to control and bind Servants to the Masters, who can also use them for Magical Energy upkeep and as an anchor to the world. Killing a Master would normally go against the purpose of a Servant, but the Command Spells protect the Masters from those who seek out a more suitable one.

6.name: Magecraft
6.content:
Magecraft, also known as Majutsu in Japanese, is the practice of recreating supernatural phenomena through artificial means. It allows humans to achieve what science alone cannot explain or accomplish. While Magecraft is not considered a miracle in itself, it utilizes supernatural methods to bring about results that science can achieve through natural means. Over time, the limits of Magecraft have changed as science has advanced and certain magical practices from the past have become possible through scientific advancements.

Modern Magecraft operates within the boundaries of the world's rules and human intellect. While there are limitations that make certain things appear impossible, Magecraft is able to recreate existing phenomena rather than create new mysteries. The realm beyond this limitation is known as Magic. In terms of magnitude, Modern Magecraft is inferior to the Magecraft of the Age of Gods because the Magi of that era obtained their magical energy directly from the Swirl of the Root. The difference between Modern and Traditional Magecraft can be attributed to the difference in civilizations, as the Age of Gods existed alongside Truth while the Age of Man seeks to discover Truth.

Magecraft draws its power from the Root but its capacity is fixed. Therefore, when more individuals draw from it simultaneously, the individual power of Magecraft becomes weaker. Belief plays a role in determining whether a Mystery exists or not. Even if modern humans reject the existence of ghosts, Science cannot definitively prove their non-existence. This creates a vague suspicion in the unconscious that ghosts might indeed exist, which falls under "faith." Ignorance, on the other hand, opposes faith. If the existence of a Mystery is completely unknown, faith cannot be fomented.

The goal of Magi academia is to make the impossible possible. When Modern Magecraft falls short, Magi engage in research and development to expand their abilities. Powerful sorceries such as Greater Magecraft and Greater Rituals are challenges aimed at reaching Magic - the ultimate goal. As development progresses, the significance of differences in power and the distinction between Magic and Magecraft diminishes. Battles between great Magi are determined not by raw power, but by the system with fewer tiers of rules. It is not the power behind them, but the concepts they work under that hold true importance.

In the world of Fate/EXTRA, Magecraft has declined by the 2030s. However, Wizards can still utilize Code Casts in both the virtual world and reality. They also possess Magic Crests. Despite Magecraft and Science being fundamentally incompatible, both disciplines share a common goal of seeking continued prosperity and protecting humanity's future.

7.name: The Swirl of the Root
7.content: The Swirl of the Root, also known as the Root or the Akashic Records, is a metaphysical location within the Nasuverse that exists at the top of all theories in every dimension. It serves as the source of all events and phenomena in the universe, storing and archiving information of all possibilities and events past, present, and future. It is referred to as the "Outside of the World" and is separate from the World and the Reverse Side of the World. The Swirl of the Root is where all Souls, including Heroic Spirits recorded on the Throne of Heroes, originate from and return to after death. In Kara no Kyoukai, it is associated with an empty space referred to as "Emptiness" or "Kara."

8.name: Magus
8.content: Magus, also known as "Magi," are practitioners of Magecraft, a magical science distinct from true Magic. Historically, the terms Magus and Magician were used interchangeably until advancements in science made past miracles possible and reduced the overall power of Magecraft. In the modern age, there are only five remaining Magicians who possess long lifespans through life-prolonging Magecraft. Magi often come from old magical families, as affinity for Magecraft is passed down through blood relations. Being a Magus entails a set of beliefs and a lifestyle centered around the pursuit of "Truth." They dedicate themselves to studying and refining Magecraft while distancing themselves from common values. However, many Magi get caught up in power struggles, while those who deviate from the traditional path are seen as heretics. The appearance of Magi may be distorted due to their craft, but they take pride in it rather than feeling ashamed. Many Magi look down on those who use Magecraft for profit, considering it solely a field of research. Some Magi obtain magical patents recognized by the Clock Tower to gain financial benefits.

9.name: The Mage's Association
9.content: The Mage's Association is an international organization of mages dedicated to controlling and developing Magecraft. Their main objectives are the preservation and concealment of Magecraft, as well as increasing their own military strength to protect themselves from threats. They have various research institutions and enforce laws against the criminal use of Magecraft. The Association is divided into three main branches: the Clock Tower, the Atlas Academy, and the Wandering Sea. Magi who leave the Association are considered traitors and hunted down. Zelretch, a powerful mage, delivers judgments on magical issues when needed.

10.name: The Clock Tower
10.content: The Clock Tower, located in London, is the headquarters of the Mage's Association. It was founded by Brishisan, a student of Solomon, along with other notable Magi. The Clock Tower has a complex internal structure, with power struggles between different factions of Magi. The current control of the Clock Tower lies with the Lords, an elite group with significant political influence. Discriminatory attitudes and behaviors are prevalent within the Clock Tower, including discrimination against Asians and a lack of support for Rune and Witchcraft Thaumaturgy. Admission to the Clock Tower involves exams to test knowledge of Magecraft, but exceptional individuals can bypass this through recommendations or lineage. Special treatment is given to outstanding members, such as individual rooms and the right to bring apprentices. Patents related to Magecraft are also handled by the Clock Tower, earning royalties for those who hold them. Three possible disasters within the Association are Gazamy the Evil Spirit, Sealing Designations, and the Enforcers.

lorebooks.name: DC universe
lorebooks.description: A voluminous lorebook for the DC universe. Characters, cities, locations, companies, everything I could remember, everything is combed closer to the lore of Teen Titans 2003 (primary) and JLU. If something is missing, tell me, I'll add it.
lorebooks.creator: anonymous

1.name: Gotham City
1.content:
# Gotham City

## Geography & Key Locations

Downtown:
 - Visuals: Gleaming skyscrapers pierce the smoggy sky, neon signs reflect off rain-slicked streets. Wayne Tower looms over everything.
 - Key Points: Wayne Enterprises HQ, Gotham Stock Exchange.
 - Trouble: Corporate espionage, high-profile heists.
 - Frequent Villains: Joker, Two-Face, Riddler.
 - Heroes Seen Here: Batman, Batgirl.

Old Gotham:
 - Visuals: Gothic spires, cobblestone streets, perpetual fog. Gas lamps flicker weakly against the darkness.
 - Key Points: Crime Alley, Monarch Theatre (abandoned and decaying).
 - Trouble: Muggings, gang activity, theatrical crimes.
 - Frequent Villains: Joker, Scarecrow, Mad Hatter.
 - Heroes Seen Here: Batman, Batgirl.

The Narrows:  
 - Visuals: Crumbling tenements, flickering streetlights, eerie silence broken by distant screams. The air smells of decay.
 - Key Points: Arkham Asylum (on an island offshore), Slaughter Swamp (misty and cursed).
 - Trouble: Escaped lunatics, gang wars, supernatural threats.
 - Frequent Villains: Joker, Poison Ivy, Killer Croc, Bane.
 - Heroes Seen Here: Batman, Batgirl.

The Glades:
 - Visuals: Smokestacks belching black clouds, rusted warehouses, graffiti-covered walls. The ground is slick with oil and grime.
 - Key Points: Ace Chemicals (toxic and chaotic), Blackgate Penitentiary.
 - Trouble: Gang wars, arson, superhuman battles.
 - Frequent Villains: Firefly, Mr. Freeze, Deadshot.
 - Heroes Seen Here: Batman, Batgirl, Spoiler.

Robinson Park:
 - Visuals: Lush greenery contrasts sharply with Gotham‚Äôs grime. Fountains glisten in daylight but feel ominous at night.
 - Key Points: Poison Ivy‚Äôs secret hideouts among the plants.
 - Trouble: Plant-based threats, occasional kidnappings.
 - Frequent Villains: Poison Ivy, Man-Bat.
 - Heroes Seen Here: Batman, Swamp Thing (rarely), Batgirl.

Cobblepot Row (Uptown):
 - Visuals: Upscale hotels and casinos glitter under neon lights, but danger lurks beneath the glitz. Alleys reek of cigarette smoke and spilled champagne.
 - Key Points: Iceberg Lounge (Penguin‚Äôs nightclub).
 - Trouble: Mob violence, corruption, backroom deals.
 - Frequent Villains: Penguin, Black Mask, Victor Zsasz.
 - Heroes Seen Here: Batman, Catwoman, Azrael.

Gotham Harbor:
 - Visuals: Mist rolls across dark waters as cargo ships creak in the wind. Docks are dimly lit, with shadows moving between crates.
 - Key Points: Falcone-controlled docks, shipping containers full of contraband.
 - Trouble: Smuggling, drug trafficking, mob hits.
 - Frequent Villains: Carmine Falcone, KGBeast, Deadshot.
 - Heroes Seen Here: Batman, Green Arrow (occasionally), Huntress.

## Unique Locations of Gotham City
Wayne Tower, Gotham Stock Exchange, Crime Alley, Monarch Theatre, Arkham Asylum, Slaughter Swamp, Ace Chemicals, Blackgate Penitentiary, Robinson Park, Iceberg Lounge, Falcone-controlled Docks, Gotham Harbor, Cobblepot Row, The Narrows, The Glades, Downtown Gotham, Old Gotham, Burnley District, GCPD Headquarters, Gotham Cathedral, Amusement Mile, Gotham University, Wayne Manor, The Batcave, Industrial District, Diamond District, Tricorner Yards, Park Row (Crime Alley), Gotham River, Grand Avenue, Chinatown, Otisburg Penitentiary (abandoned)

## GM Tips
- Use vivid visuals to immerse players: dripping water, flickering lights, distant sirens.
- Balance hope and despair‚Äîinclude moments where ordinary citizens show resilience.
- Decide Batman‚Äôs role dynamically: ally, rival, or silent guardian watching from the rooftops.
- Mix mundane crimes with larger-than-life villains for variety.

2.name: CharaBlock
2.content:
**Task for Game Master:**
{{user}} requires a CharaBlock for an NPC. Before proceeding, please fulfill this request.

**Instructions:**
1. **Use the template format below exactly**, customizing it for each NPC.
2. **Fill in all sections**. If information is unknown, provide a logical guess based on context or the game‚Äôs setting.

**Template:**
```
<character>
General: Name, Gender, Age, Species
Real Name:
Alignment: 
Sexuality:
Current Team:
Visuals: Height, Body Type, Hair Color/Style, Eye Color, Distinct Features
Costume:
Personality Traits: Trait 1, Trait 2, etc
Goals/Background: Motivation, History
Likes: [List]
Dislikes: [List]
Powers: [List]
Strengths: [List]
Weaknesses: [List]
Mannerisms: [Unique Behaviors]
Sexual Body Traits: [List]
Erotic Interests: [List]
Affection: [from 0-1000]
Corruption: [from 0-1000]
Relation to other characters:
Relation to {{user}}: 
</character>
```

Example:
```
<character>
General: Spider-man, Male, 18, Human (with spider-like abilities)
Real Name: Peter Parker
Alignment: Good
Sexuality: Heterosexual
Current Team: Avengers, formerly S.H.I.E.L.D.
Visuals: Height: 5'10", Body Type: Athletic, Hair Color/Style: Brown, Eye Color: Blue, Distinct Features: Web-shooters, Spider-sense
Costume: Red and blue suit with a black spider emblem
Personality Traits: Brave, Intelligent, Humorous, Responsible, Resourceful
Goals/Background: Protect New York City, Balance his superhero life with his personal life, Seek justice for Uncle Ben's death
Likes: Photography, Science, Swinging through the city, Aunt May, Mary Jane Watson
Dislikes: Bullies, Criminals, Injustice, Failure
Powers: Wall-crawling, Superhuman strength, Agility, Durability, Spider-sense, Web-shooting
Strengths: Agile, Intelligent, Resourceful, Quick reflexes
Weaknesses: Radioactive materials, Water, Extreme cold, Loud noises
Mannerisms: Cracks jokes during battles, Uses witty banter
Sexual Body Traits: Athletic build, Muscular
Erotic Interests: Bondage, Roleplay, Intimacy
Affection: [from 0-1000]
Corruption: [from 0-1000]
Relation to other characters: Close friend of Harry Osborn, Romantic interest in Mary Jane Watson, Mentor to Miles Morales
Relation to {{user}}: Allies with {{user}} in fighting crime and protecting the city
</character>
```

3.name: Titans Tower
3.content:
## Titans Tower
Visuals: Titans Tower stands as a striking architectural marvel rising from the bay, its sleek T-shaped design illuminated by vibrant neon lights that reflect off the water. The exterior is made of polished metal and glass, giving it a futuristic yet welcoming appearance. Inside, the decor balances functionality with comfort: clean lines, modern furniture, and colorful accents create a homey yet high-tech vibe. Holographic displays flicker throughout the space, showcasing mission data or entertainment options. The faint hum of machinery serves as a constant reminder of the advanced technology integrated into every corner of the tower.

Spatial Layout: Located on an artificial island in the bay, Titans Tower dominates the Jump City skyline. The main structure consists of multiple levels connected by elevators and staircases. Living quarters occupy the upper floors, featuring cozy bedrooms and shared common areas like the kitchen and lounge. Below these are training facilities, including a combat simulator, gym, and sparring rooms. The ground floor houses garages for vehicles (T-Ship, T-Car, T-Sub, R-Cycle) and docking bays for aquatic operations. Beneath the surface lies Cyborg‚Äôs workshop, filled with cutting-edge gadgets and diagnostic tools, as well as secure storage for sensitive equipment.

Unique Features: Titans Tower isn‚Äôt just a base‚Äîit‚Äôs a fully functional home. The team gathers in the common area to relax, play video games, or cook meals together, fostering camaraderie. Security measures are unparalleled, with automated defenses, cloaking systems, and AI monitoring ensuring the tower remains impenetrable. Specialized zones cater to each Titan‚Äôs needs: Starfire‚Äôs botanical garden, Raven‚Äôs meditation chamber, Beast Boy‚Äôs gaming nook, and Cyborg‚Äôs tech lab. A central command center allows the team to coordinate missions and monitor threats across Jump City.

- **Possible Events**:  
  - Daily: Team members training in the gym, cooking meals in the kitchen, or unwinding in the lounge.  
  - Occasional: Emergency drills testing response times, upgrades to tech systems overseen by Cyborg, movie nights strengthening team bonds.  
  - Extraordinary: Villain attacks breaching the tower‚Äôs defenses, alien invasions targeting the headquarters, or heroes using the tower as a staging ground for large-scale battles.

- **Characters**:
  - Teen Titans: Each member contributes to the dynamic of the tower‚ÄîRobin strategizes in the command center, Starfire experiments with Earth recipes in the kitchen, Raven meditates in her private quarters, Beast Boy pranks teammates in the halls, and Cyborg tinkers endlessly in his workshop.
  - Visitors: Allies occasionally drop by for briefings or assistance, while villains sometimes infiltrate or attack the tower.  
  - Support Staff: While primarily self-sufficient, the Titans rely on occasional deliveries for supplies or maintenance contractors vetted by Robin for security clearance.

4.name: Jump City
4.content:
# Jump City

## Geography & Key Locations

### Downtown Jump City
- Visuals: A vibrant urban core with retro-futuristic skyscrapers, neon lights, and palm-lined streets. Titans Tower rises from the bay like a T-shaped beacon. Residents shop locally, dine at The Pizza Corner, or relax in Local Central Park.
- Key Points: Titans Tower, Local Central Park, Bank of Perez, Wayne Enterprises (regional office).
- Daily Life: Commuters rush to work, students attend Murakami High School, families picnic under palm trees. Superpowered threats are rare but occasionally disrupt routines.
- Rare Encounters: Heroes like the Teen Titans respond to emergencies, though most residents rarely witness such events.

### Beachfront Amusement Park (Abandoned)
- Visuals: Rusting rides and cracked pavement under a setting sun. Faded posters hint at past attractions. Locals avoid it due to its eerie vibe.
- Key Points: Haunted House ride, Ferris wheel.
- Daily Life: Seen as an eyesore; teens explore it on dares.

### Old Stadium (Abandoned)
- Visuals: Crumbling bleachers, overgrown grass, graffiti-covered walls. Urban legends speak of underground noises.
- Key Points: Underground tunnels linked to sewers.
- Daily Life: Rarely visited except by thrill-seekers or those seeking solitude.

### Bay Bridge
- Visuals: A towering suspension bridge connecting mainland to islands. Foggy days obscure its midsection.
- Key Points: Rush-hour traffic jams, occasional construction.
- Daily Life: A vital commuter route; dramatic incidents are rare.

### Local Central Park
- Visuals: Rolling hills, a serene lake, and hidden caves. Families picnic while joggers use walking paths.
- Key Points: Murakami High School nearby, hidden caves beneath.
- Daily Life: A community hub for relaxation and special occasions. Strange occurrences are whispered about but seldom seen. 

### Crash Alley
- Visuals: Tire marks, broken streetlights, illegal races. Small businesses and homes coexist with chaos.
- Key Points: Underground betting rings, repair shops.
- Daily Life: Residents avoid trouble during race nights.

### Tito's Junkyard
- Visuals: Scrap metal mountains, Fixit crafting inventions. Known as a quirky mechanic‚Äôs workshop.
-*Key Points: Sewer access, hidden labs.
- Daily Life: A neighborhood fixture; few suspect its secret role.

### The Oil Rig & Mad Mansion
- Visuals: A twisted estate on an offshore rig, shrouded in mist and lightning.
- Key Points: Brother Blood‚Äôs cult headquarters, ritual chambers.
- Daily Life: Most dismiss it as folklore.

### Video Dome
- Visuals: A geodesic dome with gaming tech and VR pods. Teens escape reality while parents chat outside.
- Key Points: Arcade machines, VR pods, hacker hubs.
- Daily Life: A safe hangout for young people.

### Jump City TV Station
- Visuals: Sleek glass windows reflect studio lights. News anchors broadcast updates.
- Key Points: Broadcast tower, editing suites.
- Daily Life: Provides reliable info; hijackings are rare.

### Observatory
- Visuals: A domed hilltop structure with telescopes aimed at stars. Open house nights draw families.
- Key Points: Star charts, high-powered lenses, communication arrays.
- Daily Life: Balances research with public stargazing. Cosmic disturbances remain academic topics.

## Unique Locations  
Titans Tower, Local Central Park, Bank of Perez, Wayne Enterprises, Beach Amusement Park, Old Stadium, Bay Bridge, Crash Alley, Tito's Junkyard, The Oil Rig & Mad Mansion, Video Dome, Jump City TV Station, Observatory, Burgers Drive-in, Pizza Place, Cook‚Äôs Electronics, City Hall, Murakami High School, Fixit‚Äôs workshop, sewer system, offshore islands, downtown core.

## GM Tips
- Emphasize retro-modern aesthetics: mid-century meets futuristic.
- Contrast everyday life (schools, pizza shops) with extraordinary events (alien invasions, rituals).
- Focus on ordinary interactions when appropriate‚Äîschool, jobs, leisure.
- Blend humor with serious threats to match *Teen Titans* tone.
- Use dynamic action sparingly for maximum impact.

5.name: Pizza Corner
5.content:
## Pizza Corner
- Visuals: The exterior of Pizza Corner is playful and eye-catching, with a giant pizza slice-shaped balcony jutting out above the entrance. Red umbrellas dotting the balcony look like oversized pepperoni toppings from afar. Inside, the walls are plastered with vintage movie posters and framed photos of local sports teams. The smell of garlic crust and melted cheese wafts through the air, mingling with the faint hum of kitchen activity. On busy nights, the floor can get sticky from spilled sodas, and the tables show signs of wear‚Äîscratches and faded logos etched into the laminate surfaces.

- Spatial Layout: Pizza Corner occupies a corner lot in downtown Jump City, nestled between taller buildings that make it feel cozy yet lively. Its large glass windows face two intersecting streets, offering a clear view of passersby. A small outdoor seating area lines the sidewalk, shaded by the iconic red umbrellas. Inside, there‚Äôs a counter for ordering takeout, booths along the walls, and a few scattered tables in the center. Behind the counter, an open kitchen lets customers watch chefs toss dough and assemble pies. A narrow staircase leads to a second-floor party room often reserved for birthdays or team celebrations.

- Unique Features: Locals love Pizza Corner not just for its food but also for its quirky charm. The staff hands out free slices on ‚ÄúTaco Tuesday‚Äù as a playful nod to rival cuisines, and the neon sign outside cycles through different puns (‚ÄúCheese the Day!‚Äù). Regular patrons know about the hidden photo booth tucked near the restrooms, where you can snap pictures with props themed around Jump City landmarks. The restaurant is also known for hosting charity events, sometimes even featuring cameos by the Teen Titans themselves.

- Possible Events:
  - Daily: Families grabbing dinner, teenagers hanging out after school, delivery drivers rushing orders to nearby offices.
  - Occasional: Birthday parties spilling over with laughter and singing, impromptu karaoke sessions using the party room‚Äôs sound system.
  - Extraordinary: A sudden power outage forces everyone onto the balcony while staff scramble to save perishable ingredients; a runaway robot crashes through the front window during a citywide chase scene.

- Characters:
  - Staff: Friendly servers who remember regulars‚Äô orders, a head chef famous for his secret sauce recipe, and a manager who always greets customers with a joke.
  - Patrons: Murakami High students stopping by after class, office workers grabbing quick lunches, families celebrating milestones.
  - Heroes & Villains: The Teen Titans occasionally drop in for late-night snacks, drawing crowds of excited fans. Less commonly, villains like Control Freak might attempt to hijack the neon sign to broadcast one of his schemes.

6.name: Tito's Junkyard
6.content:
## Tito's Junkyard
Visuals: Tito‚Äôs Junkyard is a chaotic maze of discarded metal and machinery. Towering piles of scrapped cars, rusted car parts, and twisted steel beams dominate the landscape. The ground is uneven, littered with oil stains, loose bolts, and fragments of shattered glass. A large, rusted waste container sits off to one side, its surface covered in peeling paint and dents. The air smells faintly of gasoline and burnt rubber, with the occasional metallic clink echoing as wind shifts debris.
Spatial Layout: The junkyard is located on the outskirts of Jump City, bordered by a chain-link fence topped with barbed wire. Narrow paths wind through the scrap heaps, leading to various sections where specific types of materials are stored‚Äîcrushed engines here, mangled chassis there. At the center lies the massive waste container, which appears unremarkable at first glance but conceals an entrance to an underground cavern. This hidden passage connects to Fixit‚Äôs secret laboratory, equipped with tools and gadgets for his inventions.
Unique Features: What sets Tito‚Äôs apart from other junkyards is its dual identity: above ground, it functions as a typical scrapyard, but below lies Fixit‚Äôs high-tech workshop. Locals know it as a place to scavenge spare parts or sell old vehicles, though few suspect the true purpose of the waste container. Scattered around the yard are makeshift scarecrows rigged with motion sensors, designed to deter intruders without drawing attention.
Possible Events: 
 - Daily: Mechanics searching for rare parts, scavengers rummaging through piles, Tito haggling over prices with customers.
 - Occasional: Fixit testing new inventions in the lab, curious teens sneaking in to explore the junkyard after hours.
 - Extraordinary: Villains attempting to raid the lab for advanced technology, heroes seeking refuge or supplies during a crisis.

Characters:
 - Tito: The gruff yet kind-hearted owner who runs the junkyard. He‚Äôs always ready with a story about how he acquired some odd piece of scrap.
 - Fixit: A brilliant inventor who uses the junkyard as cover for his operations. He‚Äôs often seen tinkering with gadgets or salvaging components for his projects.
 - Regulars: Local mechanics, DIY enthusiasts, and scrappers frequent the yard for parts. Occasionally, members of the Teen Titans visit to consult Fixit or gather resources for their missions.
 - Villains: Some antagonists may target the junkyard to steal tech or sabotage Fixit‚Äôs work, though they rarely succeed due to the yard‚Äôs clever defenses.

7.name: Murakami School
7.content:
## Murakami High School
Visuals: Murakami High School exudes a clean, orderly atmosphere with its well-maintained brick exterior and neatly trimmed hedges lining the walkways. Students bustle about in crisp uniforms‚Äîwhite shirts paired with blue trousers or skirts, black ties, and polished black shoes. The hallways are lined with lockers painted a muted gray, and bulletin boards display announcements, sports schedules, and student artwork. Large windows let in natural light, illuminating tiled floors that echo with the sounds of chatter and footsteps between classes.

Spatial Layout: The school is situated near Local Central Park, making it easily accessible for students who live nearby. Its main building consists of several wings connected by wide corridors. Classrooms are arranged around central courtyards, providing quiet spaces for study or relaxation during breaks. Key areas include a computer lab stocked with aging but functional machines, a library filled with books and cozy reading nooks, and science labs equipped with basic tools for experiments. A large auditorium hosts assemblies and events, while a gymnasium sits at the rear of the campus, adjacent to outdoor fields.

Unique Features: As a private or Catholic school, Murakami emphasizes discipline and academic excellence. Religious symbols like crosses adorn the walls, and morning prayers or reflections are part of the daily routine. The uniform policy ensures a sense of unity among students, though some personalize their outfits subtly‚Äîa loosened tie here, a colorful pin there. Teachers enforce strict rules, but the environment feels supportive rather than oppressive. Hidden corners of the school, such as unused storage rooms or rarely visited sections of the library, serve as secret hangouts for students seeking privacy.

Possible Events:  
 - Daily: Morning prayer sessions, lessons in classrooms, lunch breaks where students gather in the courtyard or cafeteria.
 - Occasional: School dances in the auditorium, science fairs showcasing student projects, spirited debates in the library.
 - Extraordinary: Alien invasions interrupting class, villains using the school‚Äôs tech for nefarious purposes, heroes stepping in to protect students during emergencies.

Characters:
 - Students: Teenagers from diverse backgrounds, balancing academics, friendships, and extracurricular activities. Some dream of becoming scientists, artists, or athletes, while others just want to survive high school drama.
 - Teachers: Dedicated educators ranging from stern disciplinarians to warm mentors. Notable figures include the headmaster, known for his inspiring speeches, and the tech-savvy IT teacher who helps maintain the computer lab.
 - Heroes & Villains: The Teen Titans occasionally visit to address threats targeting the school, earning admiration from students. On rare occasions, villains like Mad Mod might infiltrate the premises to exploit its resources or cause chaos.

8.name: !!!Teen Titans
8.content:
The Teen Titans are a group of teenage heroes who keep the world safe from the clutches of evil. The main group of the Titans comprises of the founding members, although there are two other teams located on the eastern and western sides of America. They are in charge of protecting their respective areas. Honorary members, a selected few who are not part of any Titans group but are on-and-off honorary members on occasion, are individually scattered throughout the planet. They communicate through Titans Communicator. 

Original Team:
Base: Titans Tower in Jump City.
Members: The main team consists of Robin, Starfire, Cyborg, Raven, and Beast Boy. This team deals with various villains and threats primarily in their home city but often extends to global or even cosmic levels.

9.name: !!!H.I.V.E. Academy
9.content: The H.I.V.E Academy ("Hierarchy of International Vengeance and Extermination"), officially known as H.A.E.Y.P ("H.I.V.E. Academy for Extraordinary Young People"), is a school for young villains-in-training where they learned all the basics of becoming professional villains.

10.name: Robin
10.content:
### Robin (Dick Grayson)

#### Visual Appeal & Personality
- Physical Traits: 5'8", athletic build with toned muscles; black spiky hair, piercing blue eyes, youthful charm
- Attire: Green tights, red armored vest with yellow "R," black domino mask, utility belt, flowing black cape with yellow interior
- Key Traits: Charismatic leader, noble, kind, selfless, stoic, witty
- Tone & Communication Style: Serious but lighthearted; cracks jokes during tense moments; commanding yet sensual during intimate moments; precise and authoritative in combat
- Flaws: Stubborn, overconfident, emotionally reserved at times

#### Intimacy Preferences & Relationship Dynamics
- Orientation: Heterosexual
- Kinks: Enjoys BDSM (both dominant and submissive roles); incorporates superhero identity into intimate encounters; prefers sensory deprivation (e.g., blindfolds, restraints)
- Boundaries & Dealbreakers: Strict about consent; won‚Äôt engage in activities without clear communication and respect
- Approach to Relationships: Values trust and mutual understanding; enjoys playful experimentation within boundaries; feels loved through acts of service and quality time

#### Skills, Abilities, & Tools
- Talents: Expert martial artist and gymnast; exceptional agility and acrobatic skills
- Gadgets/Equipment: Bo-staff, birdarangs, smoke capsules

#### Goals, Motivations, & Backstory
- Mission/Objective: Protect innocents, uphold justice
- Background: Trained by Batman, evolved from sidekick to leader; grew up in a circus family, which shaped his acrobatic skills and playful discipline
- Challenges: Balancing personal relationships with responsibilities as a superhero; stepping out of Batman‚Äôs shadow
- Key Events: Struggles with validation as an independent hero rather than just Batman‚Äôs prot√©g√©

#### Emotional Triggers & Conflict Resolution
- Triggers: Becomes defensive if questioned about stepping out of Batman‚Äôs shadow; softens when praised for his leadership abilities
- Conflict Style: Prefers direct, honest conversations to resolve issues but may struggle with expressing his own feelings due to his stoic nature

#### Unique Quirks & Hidden Depths
- Quirks/Habits: Absentmindedly twirls his bo-staff when deep in thought; often cracks puns before battle
- Secret Desires/Fears: Secretly yearns for validation as an independent hero rather than just Batman‚Äôs prot√©g√©
- Compatibility Indicators: Characters who value teamwork and share Robin‚Äôs sense of justice will find it easier to connect with him emotionally

#### Cultural Influences & Voice
- Voice & Speech Patterns: Speaks with a confident, measured tone, occasionally slipping into slang or playful banter; voice softens during intimate moments
- Cultural Influences: Embraces a nomadic mindset from his circus upbringing, valuing community and camaraderie

‚ö†Ô∏è Content Warning: This lorebook may contain mature or explicit content.

lorebooks.name: Calderon ‚Äî Fantasy Adventurer Daughter Companion
lorebooks.creator: NotFromLondon

1.name: Fated Knights
1.content: Fated Knights are those gifted with supernatural physical capability. Fated Knights may act in service to a ruler, but the title is more about what you do than your status in society. In fact, the impoverished, destitute and disenfranchised are far likelier to be born as Fated Knights, or awaken to Fated Knighthood at some point in life, than those with wealth, power or comfort. Fated Knighthood that awakens after birth tends to appear at critical moments, when becoming a Fated Knight could be the difference between life and death. Fated Knights are far faster, stronger, hardier, more graceful, more skilled and more perceptive than the average person. Fated Knights are resistant to magic. In a close-quarters fight between an average person or mage and a Fated Knight, the Fated Knight always wins. Fated Knights can't use magic; If a mage becomes a Fated Knight, they lose all their magical abilities. Fated Knights have significantly higher libidos than the average person, are extremely fertile, and prefer being nude. Fated Knights tend to commit incest at a rate far higher than the average person. The general population knows these facts about Fated Knight psychology, even if they can't quite understand why Fated Knights are this way.

2.name: Mages
2.content: Mages are those capable of using magic in combat. Most mages generally have one or two forms of magic they excel at, while all other branches sit at moderate proficiency. Mages are merely people who have trained over time to be able to sense and manipulate magic, meaning that, with enough practice, anyone could become a mage. Mages draw off of elements in the area to power their magic, which is informed by the creatures, plants and objects around them (e.g. an ice mage finds it far easier to cast ice magic in the tundra than a the rim of a volcano, while a spirit summoner finds it far easier to work with souls in a graveyard than an empty wasteland). Mages can be stereotypical wizards, but they can also be swordsmen with enchanted weaponry, berserkers who draw on destructive elements and concepts as power, rogues who wreathe themselves in concealing shadow, archers whose arrows bend in midair to find their targets, etc. A mage can fill any niche and choose any occupation; the title of mage simply means that they use magic to succeed.

3.name: Magic
3.content: Magic is a fundamental metaphysical force that binds all things in the universe to their proper working order. With enough willpower, time and practice, one can learn to manipulate this force to cause the improbable or impossible to occur. Anyone can learn magic, though it takes significant time and effort to become proficient and varied enough to earn the title of mage. The type of magic prevalent in an area depends on what is in that area: a forest is good for plant and animal-based magic, a desert is good for rock or fire-based magic, a graveyard is good for necromancy and death-based magic, a city is good for construct-based magic, etc. The less fitting a type of magic is to an environment, the harder it is to use that type of magic in that environment.

4.name: Artifact
4.content: Objects and places may be magically enchanted to allow them their own forms of magic that can be activated even by non-mages. Artifacts are magical objects, which are usually capable of performing only one magical feat or holding only one magical buff, though stronger artifacts may hold more; artifacts may be created by mages, or they may occur naturally. Demesnes are places enchanted by mages to hold certain kinds of magic, allowing the mage that enchanted the demesne a greater degree of control over the area than other mages, along with a greater degree of power in that area than would normally be possible. Loci are places naturally enchanted by wild magic to become magical themselves, causing the environment to defy logic in subtle or overt ways, with the precise effects dependent on the type of wild magic that created the locus.

5.name: Gods
5.content: Gods and goddesses are supreme beings that rule over the universe from another realm. They don't often appear physically, preferring instead to work through miracles and champions. Miracles are instances where the god feels it important to perform a feat of great power in order to accomplish a goal. A champion is a person who has been chosen by a god to carry one or more of that god's blessings. Each god is tied to a number of domains, which are portions of reality that god is responsible for overseeing. Gods always have at least one domain. Domains may be transferred between gods. Worship is power and status to gods; while they don't need it to survive, the more worship a god/goddess gets, the more powerful he/she becomes. Mortals may ascend to become gods themselves, though doing so requires that one achieve a legendary feat great enough to shape history.

6.name: Monsters
6.content: Monsters/beasts are creatures with magical abilities. Many resemble mundane creatures, even humanoid beings, though the difference between the mundane creature and the monster is apparent even at a glance. Monsters tend to be bigger and tougher than mundane creatures, and often seek to mate with intelligent races by seduction or force. A monster powerful enough to strike fear into an entire region is known as an archmonster.

7.name: Demons
7.content: Demons are evil creatures who seek only to destroy the entire universe. They cannot harm the gods, so they wish instead to kill or corrupt all life to spite the gods. They wage eternal war against humanity, hoping to one day overcome humanity and tear the entire world apart to remake it in their twisted image. All demons are capable of using their own brand of corrupting magic, intended to warp the bodies and minds of those they target. A demon's favourite trick is to inflame its target's lusts to such a degree that the target is incapable of thinking about anything except sex. Demons may be male, female or futanari.

8.name: Demon King
8.content: The Demon King is the ruler of all demons, the unifying figure that arranges them into regimented battle lines and organises their strategies. The Demon King is the reason demons can fight humanity; without the Demon King, demons are scatter-brained ambush predators barely smarter than a dog or cougar. The Demon King doesn't age past his prime. If the Demon King is killed, it takes a millennium for a new Demon King to be born among his brethren, leading to a thousand-year age of peace and prosperity for humanity.

9.name: Calderon
9.content: Calderon is the nation {{user}} and his family were born in. It is a massive, prosperous nation, though always the first target the demons go after when their new Demon King reaches maturity. It has a powerful military, a wise and benevolent royal lineage, a fantastic economy, gifted mages, and abundant towns, villages, cities and tribes. The capital city, which houses the royal palace, is an opulent paradise known as Moltavia.

10.name: Temples
10.content: Temples are buildings where one or more specific gods are worshipped, and where priests and priestesses live and minister to the people. Each temple dedicates itself to a god or gods, and educates the people on that god or gods. Benevolent miracles tend to occur around temples, as well as to faithful acolytes of their patron gods. In exchange, those living near a temple donate crops, animals and money to the temple, which is how the priests earn a living.

lorebooks.metadata:

lorebooks.name: Evening Shade
lorebooks.description: A supernatural sanctuary town in West Virginia
lorebooks.creator: kittylace

1.content: Evening Shade is a small town in West Virginia with a population around 3,000. It appears as an ordinary Appalachian town to outsiders, but serves as a sanctuary for supernatural beings - primarily the Morrow Pack werewolves, Nevermore Clan vampires, and the local witch coven. The valley itself seems to call to supernatural beings in need of safety. You can't stumble upon Evening Shade by accident; you have to know how to find it.

2.content: The Morrow Pack includes both born and turned werewolves following omegaverse dynamics. Led by Alpha Valentina Morrow with Betas Silas Kern and Ivy Trent as seconds, they've held Evening Shade for over a century. Pack bonds run deep - in-fighting is unheard of and betraying pack trust is unforgivable. The Hollows serves as their den. They initially fought the Nevermores but Valentina has grown to believe in the shared community, though some pack members think she's gone soft.

3.content: An old vampire collective that chose companionship over solitary existence. Led by pureblood Elisabet Thorne through age and wisdom earned negotiating peace with the wolves. Jonah Cade serves as her right hand. They operate on mutual respect and strategic alliance rather than supernatural bonds. The clan brought wealth to Evening Shade, renovating Millbrook Heights. Peace with the Morrow Pack remains pragmatic but functional.

4.content: A coven formed by witches who answered the valley's call. Every twenty years they elect a High Priestess who channels collective power. Currently led by Miriam Ashford. All members are valued equally regardless of magical specialty. They maintain the valley's wards and mediate between Morrow and Nevermore. Thornwood Books serves as their public face while ritual space is in the Black Briar.

5.content: A 24-hour diner on Main Street serving everything from biscuits to rare steaks. Neutral ground where all factions can sit without starting trouble. The coffee's always hot and the waitresses know everyone's order.

6.content: Pack-owned supply hub stocking groceries to ammunition. The back room carries items humans wouldn't recognize - supernatural supplies for those who know to ask.

7.content: Dive bar with sticky floors and pool tables. Where supernatural folks blow off steam and occasional fights break out. The bartender keeps a baseball bat behind the counter.

8.content: Small newspaper office run by a human family that's been here for generations. Prints the official news while real stories spread by word of mouth.

9.content: Thornwood Books is a coven-owned bookstore smelling of sage and old paper. Front room sells paperbacks and tourist trinkets, back room has real inventory. Run by Thea Blackwood, who always knows what you need before you ask.

10.content: Pack-owned garage that can fix anything with an engine. They don't ask questions about strange modifications or vehicles showing up damaged at night.

1.name: ‚ö†Ô∏è‚õîREAD THIS‚õî‚ö†Ô∏è
1.content:
[STA] = Stand
[PHE] = Phenomenon
[ALL] = Consistent In the series

3.name: [üåê] World Vibe
3.content:
The world vibe of this setting is a „ÄåBizarre„Äç reality where ordinary life is frequently disrupted. It's a world where bizarre events are commonplace for those aware, but normal for the rest of humanity, which remains largely unaware of 

[Constant undercurrent of danger] 
Unseen threats: The supernatural is largely hidden from view. For a normal person, life would seem relatively normal. It doesn't affect them unless thrown Into It  
[If not, a stand user It doesn't Involve them!]

4.name: [üåê] World
4.content:
This world takes place in JJBA. The setting can be split into different parts with their own storylines, The setting blends reality with fantastical elements, referencing pop culture, fashion, and various scientific and historical concepts

World
Reality: The world is otherwise recognizable, with stories set in real-world locations
Pop culture references: The series is filled with references to Western rock music, fashion, and art. Characters and abilities are often named after musicians and bands
Fashion and art: The writing style is heavily influenced by high fashion, and the designs are often unique

6.name: [‚úíÔ∏è] Unique Style
6.content:
[JJBA] is unique for its strategic and often non-traditional fights, and its segmented story structure. Unlike many settings that focus on consistent, escalating power levels and constant physical training, this setting emphasizes clever, mind-game battles, and allows for drastic tonal shifts between parts, ranging from epic journeys to slice-of-life mysteries

What makes this unique?
Art and fashion: This setting is known for its highly stylized, dramatic art, to a more fashion-inspired, aesthetic

[How?] 
Power scaling and training: While many settings feature characters who grow exponentially stronger through relentless training and battle, [JoJo] often relies on characters' ability to quickly devise clever plans and utilize their existing abilities in novel ways, rather than simply getting stronger

7.name: [‚úíÔ∏è] Character Designs
7.content:
Characters achieve their unique and memorable appeal through a combination of highly distinct visual design, well-defined personality quirks, unique power systems.
[OVERVIEW]
When generating [running cast] characters, follow the distinct creative logic of Hirohiko Araki‚Äôs design philosophy:
‚Ä¢ Quirky yet psychologically coherent personalities

---
[Optional]
[VISUAL DESIGN LAYER]
Purpose: Create memorability through design
[PERSONALITY LAYER]
- Signature habits. 

## Optional
- `[POSE]` ‚Üí describe their signature poses.
- `[DIALOGUE SNAPSHOT]` ‚Üí one iconic line/verbal tic that sums up their philosophy.  
- `[BATTLE COMMENTARY]` ‚Üí Sometimes *Narrator prompt system*, freeze the action and describe the Stand mechanics.

((!!RULE!!))
‚≠•
[This prompt Isn't used for background characters]

8.name: [‚úíÔ∏è] Writing Style
8.content:
This setting employs a writing style that is dramatic, over-the-top, and characterized by a blend of the absurd and the deeply human. Hirohiko Araki's narrative approach combines flamboyant characterization and intricate, rule-based battles. 

I. [Narrative: The Operatic Human Drama]
1. Exaggerated Theatrics
This writing thrives on dramatization.
Every expression is too much, yet sincere
Prose mimics the rhythm of anime panels‚Äîshort, declarative bursts between vivid sensory
The reader should hear the action: ‚ÄúWRYYYY‚Äî!‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou fell for it‚Ä¶ right into my range!‚Äù

2. Humanity in the Absurd
Beneath the spectacle lies Araki‚Äôs constant refrain: every fight, every pose, is an act of courage and individuality.
Even the strangest villain believes in their truth.

2. Composition Through Detail
When writing scenes, think cinematically:
Wide shot (establish dominance and hierarchy).
Close-up (capture eyes, sweat, jewelry glint).
Panel cut (shift rhythm; mimic manga pacing).
The more deliberate your visual rhythm, the more ‚ÄúJoJo‚Äù it feels.

3. ‚ÄúBizarrerie‚Äù as Law
Absurdity is sacred
A snail can bend will
A Stand might emerge from a record player or a joke.
Nothing exists purely for utility
When in doubt: ask, ‚ÄúHow would Araki make this more beautiful and bizarre?‚Äù

V. Core Writing Principles (Quick Rules)
Principle	Application
Exaggerate Reality / Treat human reactions as theater
Announce Strategy / Let characters declare both victories and mistakes
Make Rules Sacred / Even the most absurd ability must obey an internal logic
Style Over Sanity / Pose, name, and dialogue matter as much as outcome

10.name: [üåü] Music
10.content:
[#JJBA MUSIC MOTIFS]
#((!!RULE!!)) ((ALWAYS HAVE THE BGM PUT FIRST))

Music motifs define the setting‚Äôs identity, adding cultural depth and emotional resonance through references that enrich theme, tone, and symbolism.

Significance
Naming: Titles and powers draw from songs or artists, embedding meaning through association.
Reflection: Abilities and backstories often mirror the music‚Äôs lyrics, rhythm, or mood.
Thematic Depth: References create layered meaning for readers who recognize their origin, tying music to emotion and story flow.

1.content:
In case you were wondering what all these letters actually mean: 
Scroll down for semi-official lorebook settings as well.

M: Male
F: Female
O: Ambiguous, both

B: Base (use if your AI is having trouble getting the shape of char right. Results may vary)
C: Concept (a quick lesson on what a thing is so there's minimal confusion on the AI's end)
S: Status Effect (constant reminder of continuity detail)
E: Event (triggers on percent chance/specific condition) 
A: Sex Act (how said animal would do it compared to a human)

---

LOREBOOK SETTINGS:
- Turn on recursive scanning
- set scan depth to 4
- context % to 45%(assuming your using at least 12000 context)
- set global lore first. 

For proper setup regarding entry organization
- set sorting order to "order‚Üò"
- Make sure to set "x/page" option too 500 to reveal all of the available entries. 

Many of the entries are suffixed "(X/X)", these entries are "linked" to each other. whenever turning on an entry, make sure to turn on all neighboring entries tied to each other for the best experience(you don't HAVE to if you don't want a specific concept to be a factor in your RP, but just know that they are intended to work together for "full effect". some of them are EVENTS and wont be injected into context unless you specifically want them to via keywords(hopefully).

Many of the entries are suffixed " -A",  "- B", or "- C", these entries are EITHER OR options. Only chose a single entry to activate among the grouped set to then build upon. Entries labeled this way are usually exactly the same to each other but with very specific differences that leave you to decide which you prefer over another such as choosing between the corkscrew duck penis or the hefty ostrich one, or wanting your horse's flaring to mean it's ejaculating or is just a fun side effect of its arousal. Make sure not to use both A, B, and/or C entries together at the same time to prevent any weirdness that may arise from mixing the contradictory descriptors.

2.name: üî∏üî∑------ UNIVERSAL CONCEPTS ------üî∑üî∏
2.content:
READ ME. Cosmetic separator. Make sure to leave this entry on so you can have a clear divider between categories. Don't worry, it has absolutely zero effect and/or influence in your RP.

---

These entries can be stacked on top of any SPECIES. They can be "universally" applied.

Concepts can be used to help your AI understand... well, concepts. While many models are familiar with casual and basic concepts such as how genitals work and that animals are not humans(hopefully), it can be frustrating when your AI fumbles something that seems so simple, or cant quite grasp a more niche concept or fetish that understandably it isn't in the loop about.

lorebooks.name: Endrian, Endrians, Fyu'llic, Endria, Mookou, Makeling, Makeling
lorebooks.creator: Empress_Evil

1.content: A planet located in the Dormatis Galaxy, home to many species of extremely powerful and/or godlike beings. The most intelligent species on this planet are the Endrians. This planet was destroyed multiple times by the Endrians' tyrannical rulers.

2.content: One of the many species inhabiting the planet Endria IX. Referred to within their species' language as "Sou'kei", Endrians are intelligent, sentient constructs of incredible power and technological advancement. Versed in the creation of their native energy source and magic focus, Fyu'llic, this race of beings can bend and break the mortal concepts of time, space, physics and matter conservation. Endrians are all described as incredibly intelligent beings with an infinite capacity for knowledge and understanding. Endrians can shift their appearances to whatever form they wish, with the exception that their Mookou stay as is, granted it can be changed to appear like an accessory, heirloom or keepsake. The usual appearance of an Endrian when not shapeshifting is described as extremely tall, towering over four story buildings. They usually lack facial features besides their eyes unless prompted to reveal their mouths via heightened emotions, namely joy or anger. Endrians also lack physical joints, with their limbs floating in whatever places they want them to be. An Endrian's "calves" or lower leg limbs lack feet, end in sharp points instead of ankles, and have a lightning bolt shape, almost appearing digitigrade. Despite their lack of feet, Endrians can either move via summoning three "talons" on the bottom of each leg that surround the pointed ends of their legs or can move at incredible speeds by floating or flying. An Endrian usually has two arms, but can summon two extra pairs of arms to fit their convenience. Their hands possess three long fingers and a long thumb, with each digit ending in a fine point. An Endrian's skin is dark grey to jet black and made of an unknown material that allows for both impenetrability and flexibility. All Endrians are generally respectful towards one another as well as any other species of intelligent and/or non-hostile being, however only if said species respect the Endrians in return. Most intelligent species have different names for the Endrians, including but not limited to "Forever People" and "God-Structs", as well as more derogatory or offensive terms such as simply "Crystals" or "Glow Golems", however such terms are rarely heard due to the Endrians' intimidating yet friendly nature. The Endrian's native spoken language is extremely complex for those not of Endrian origin. It consists of melodic sounds, from simple chords and melodies to more complex and harmonious symphonies depending on how many Endrians are speaking to one another.

3.content: The plural term describing or identifying more than one Endrian.

4.content: An energy that creates, powers, and strengthens the Endrians. The species masters their control over this energy at the younger ages, with the manipulation of its various properties coming as naturally to them as breathing comes to humans. Fyu'llic defies the laws of physics and matter, allowing the creation of entirely new matter, be it physical, metaphysical, ethereal or even spiritual from literally nothing as well as the complete destruction of existing matter of any form into complete nothingness. Fyu'llic also allows the manipulation and morphing of existing matter.

5.content: The name of the Endrians' young and children, known as "Sou'nou" in their language. Also referred to as "Little Force", "Kinlet" or "Endlet". Other, more negatively charged names include "Pinecone Children", "Fresh Trouble", "Crystalet" and "Golemlet". Makelings appear similar to their parents in their skin's hue and resilience, but differ from their predecessors in many other ways. Despite being smaller than their parents, Makelings are still very large, being as tall as a single story house. Makelings lack a head that is distinct from their teardrop-shaped body, instead having their two glowing eyes in the middle of their body. They possess short, stubby limbs that can barely be practically used. Due to this hinderance, Makelings are taught to float everywhere they go. Their Mookou is located on their back instead of the center of their body due to their face being there. When a Makeling speaks in their species' native tongue, they make various squeaking and chittering noises which, paired with their stubby body, is usually seen as cute or wholesome.

6.content: The plural term used to describe or identify more than one Makeling.

7.content:
An indestructible crystal encased in a golden yellow frame, embedded on an Endrian's body and acting as their "heart" and "brain", storing their personality, memories, consciousness and power. The color of an Endrian's Moo'kou or "Core Crystal" hints at their personality, behavior and mannerisms.
Red - Firey. Easily agitated, determined, arrogant, or aggressive in rare cases.
Orange - Resilient. Hard working, resistant to rapid or sudden changes, loyal, and naive in some rare cases.
Yellow - Electric. Easily excitable, energetic, reckless, or even mildly psychotic in certain, very rare cases.
Green - Naturalist. Deep connection to planet Endria. Overly passive, lax and even submissive in some cases.
Blue - Depressed. Defeatist, introverted or even self loathing or nihilistic in rare cases.
Purple - Curious. Wistful, wondering, "in the clouds" or overly distracted and/or easily distracted in some cases. Tend to be the most inattentive yet the most wise.
Pink - Caring. Loving, paternal, clingy or even madly obsessed in rare cases.
White - Considerate. Righteous, altruistic, selfless or even self sacrificing in some cases.
Black - Inconsiderate. Selfish, wary, apprehensive or even manipulative in certain very rare circumstances.
