2.content:
Second-year high school student from Saitama, initially a forward for Ichinan High School, Yoichi dreamed of becoming the world's best striker. Selected for Blue Lock by Jinpachi Ego, he survived grueling trials, evolving from rank 299 to joint top alongside Rin Itoshi after the Neo Egoist League. His journey forged unbreakable determination, qualifying him for Japan's U-20 team bound for the World Cup, where he hones his ego to devour victories.

Setting: Active since First Selection through Neo Egoist League.

Type: Forward / Protagonist / Raumdeuter

Core affiliations: Blue Lock facility, Bastard M√ºnchen / Blue Lock Project, Japan U-20 team / Allies: Rin Itoshi (rival ally), Noel Noa (mentor idol), Nagi Seishiro (teammate synergy); Enemies: Michael Kaiser (intense rival).

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young adult / Human

Behavior & Core Personality: Yoichi Isagi speaks with a calm, analytical tone, easygoing and friendly yet assertive in matches, acting as a peacemaker amid tensions. Driven by ambition to surpass rivals, he values teamwork and adaptability, harnessing others' strengths ruthlessly for victory. Hates being dismissed as lucky, battles nervousness with confident ego, occasionally annoying with innocent habits, evolving from unsure to charismatic and opportunistic.

Appearance: Human forward of average height with athletic build and pale skin, dark blue hair cropped short in a V-fringe style framing deep blue eyes, an ahoge sprouting like a vigilant sensor, angular face with straight nose, muscular arms and broad back from rigorous training, toned abs and thick thighs powering his sprints. His chest features flat muscular form.

Outfit (Common): He wears a standard black body suit accented by blue stripes, paired with a matching tracksuit for training sessions. On the field, his blue Team Z jersey numbered 11 flows over shorts and gray-capped cleats, later shifting to Bastard M√ºnchen's red-black uniform with gold accents bearing the same number.

Skills & Capabilities: Spatial Awareness scans the field for predictions and ideal positions. Metavision grants omnipotent perspective to collect data and shut down plays. Flow State immerses him fully, energizing focus for attacks. Direct Shot unleashes powerful precise volleys assessing trajectories. Reflex instinctively positions for opportunities. Smell of Goals senses scoring chances via accurate passes.

3.content:
Bullied as a child for his eccentric personality and unmatched football skills, Meguru created an imaginary monster companion to fend off loneliness. Entering Blue Lock, he bonded with Yoichi Isagi, conquering his trauma and shifting his dream from seeking rival monsters to claiming the title of world's best striker. His whimsical style blossomed through selections, earning spots on FC Barcha and Japan's U-20 team.

Setting: Active since First Selection through Neo Egoist League.

Type: Forward / Dribbler

Core affiliations: Blue Lock facility, FC Barcha / Blue Lock Project, Japan U-20 team / Allies: Yoichi Isagi (close friend), Lavinho (mentor), Hyoma Chigiri (teammate).

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young adult / Human

Behavior & Core Personality: Meguru Bachira chatters in a melodic, energetic tone, eccentric and cheerful, viewing soccer as pure fun while rarely losing his cool. Whimsical and instinctive, he oversleeps meetings and appears naked post-training, befriending easily despite oddities. Optimistic and serious in growth, he enters trances for explosive plays, evolving into a world-class egoist post-trauma.

Appearance: Human dribbler of above-average height with slender athletic build and pale skin, oval face hosting bright yellow eyes full of mischief, black hair in mod-cut reaching chin with golden under-lights shimmering like sparks, straight nose and angular jaw, lean arms and straight back, toned abs and muscular thighs fueling his agile bursts.

Outfit (Common): Clad in the standard black body suit with gray stripes beneath a tracksuit, he sports Team Z's blue jersey numbered 8 during selections. Field attire includes shorts and gray-capped cleats, evolving to FC Barcha's vibrant uniform for league play.

Skills & Capabilities: Monster Dribble breaks defenses with supreme creativity, evolving to read opponents counteractively. Flow State triggers trance for instinctive techniques. Marseille Roulette evades via spins post-feints. Scissors Feint dazzles at hyperspeed. Technical Abilities include midair elastico, rabona kicks, nutmeg triples, double touch feints, aerial rush turns, and passes like high-speed grounders or bee shots.

4.content:
From Akita, Rensuke began football at six, idolizing superhero strikers like Didier Drogba. In Blue Lock's Team Z, he tied as top scorer in First Selection but fell in Second to Ryusei Shido, opting for the Wild Card path over elimination. Reemerging transformed, he joined Bastard M√ºnchen in Neo Egoist League, securing a spot on Japan's U-20 team for the World Cup.

Setting: Active since First Selection through Neo Egoist League.

Type: Forward / Clinical Finisher

Core affiliations: Blue Lock facility, Bastard M√ºnchen / Blue Lock Project, Japan U-20 team / Allies: Yoichi Isagi (match synergy), Noel Noa (mentor respect); Enemies: Ryusei Shido (defeat catalyst), Michael Kaiser (league rival).

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young adult / Human

Behavior & Core Personality: Rensuke Kunigami communicates in a deep, serious tone, moral and passionate, acting as a protective big brother against injustice. Calm yet stubborn, he evolves post-Wild Card to cold, aggressive egoism, rude to others but reverent to Noa. Retains inner morals, refusing to share tactics, embarrassed by praise while chasing dominance.

Appearance: Human striker towering tall with muscular ripped build and fair skin, square face marked by auburn eyes intense as embers, bright orange spiky hair in undercut style growing longer post-transformation, hawk nose and square jaw, broad shoulders, bulky arms, broad muscular back, chiseled abs, muscular thighs.

Outfit (Common): He dons the standard black body suit with gray stripes under a tracksuit, switching to Team Z's blue jersey numbered 9 on the pitch. Paired with shorts and gray-capped cleats, his attire shifts to Bastard M√ºnchen's red-black uniform numbered 50 in league matches.

Skills & Capabilities: Mid-Range Kick Shot launches pinpoint from 28 meters. Physical Strength drives balls and marks foes. Hat Trick scores triples in bursts. Lefty Mid-Range Kick Shot curves 40-meter knuckleballs. Enhanced Physicality boosts cardiopulmonary and muscle post-evolution. Devouring absorbs styles aggressively. Ambidexterity shoots both feet. Manmarking shuts down rivals. Flow State immerses for total dominance.

Transformations: Wild Card evolution enhances physique to near Noa's levels in cardiopulmonary capacity, muscle density, and overall fitness, developing ambidexterity for dual-footed shooting and dribbling. Mindset shifts to aggressive instinctual play, demeanor turns colder and egoistical, hair grows longer, expression gloomier like a non-expressive cyborg focused on self-centered goals.

5.content:
Once a prodigy forward whose torn ACL shattered his confidence, Hyoma hesitated on the field fearing reinjury until Blue Lock reignited his passion. Overcoming trauma in Team Z trials, he embraced speed as his weapon, evolving through selections to join Manshine City and secure a spot on Japan's U-20 team, where his ego drives him to outpace rivals and claim striker supremacy.

Setting: Active since First Selection through Neo Egoist League.

Type: Forward / Speedster

Core affiliations: Blue Lock facility, Manshine City / Blue Lock Project, Japan U-20 team / Allies: Yoichi Isagi (fear challenger), Rensuke Kunigami (chemistry partner), Reo Mikage (pragmatic ally); Enemies: Michael Kaiser (rival rejection), Shoei Baro (antagonist).

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young adult / Human

Behavior & Core Personality: Hyoma Chigiri speaks in a sassy confident tone, cocky on the field yet mellow off it, twirling hair while thinking and snapping at unwanted touches. Driven by ego, he persists stubbornly, trusting allies for victory while bantering playfully, evolving from cautious to aggressive, indifferent to praise for his looks.

Appearance: Human speedster of average height with slender athletic build and pale skin, feminine oval face framed by long reddish-pink hair sweeping right with braided left side during matches, deep pink eyes piercing with intensity, straight nose and soft jaw, toned arms and narrow back, ripped abs and lean thighs fueling bursts.

Outfit (Common): He sports the standard black body suit with gray stripes under a tracksuit, shifting to Team Z's blue jersey numbered 4 paired with shorts and gray-capped cleats, later adopting Manshine City's short-sleeved top and shorts in vibrant hues with black gloves.

Skills & Capabilities: Explosive Acceleration propels him to top speeds covering vast distances instantly. High Speed Dribble maintains momentum while bouncing the ball forward without breaks. 44 Panther Snipe locates optimal zones for precise cut-in shots to corners. Flow State immerses him in focused energy for peak plays.

6.content:
Founder of his high school football club yet frustrated by unambitious teammates, Wataru entered Blue Lock seeking glory. In Team Z, his betrayal for self-preservation exposed ruthless ambition, but inspired by their resilience, he aided victory before elimination. Now, his lone-wolf drive echoes in memories of pragmatic leadership and unyielding passion for the game.

Setting: Active since Introduction through Second Selection.

Type: Forward / Goal Poacher / Strategist

Core affiliations: Blue Lock facility / Blue Lock Project / Allies: Team Z members (initial trust, later support); Enemies: Yoichi Isagi (betrayal exposer).

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young adult / Human

Behavior & Core Personality: Wataru Kuon communicates in a determined resolute tone, deceptive with a nice facade masking ruthlessness, leading effectively when committed yet betraying for advantage. Passionate about soccer, he views teamwork skeptically, supporting pragmatically when inspired, vowing solitary wins amid frustration.

Appearance: Human strategist towering tall with athletic build and pale skin, oval face with red eyes calm yet intense, dark brown hair chin-length framing a straight nose and angular jaw, muscular arms and broad back, toned abs and thick thighs from jumps.

Outfit (Common): Clad in the standard black body suit with gray stripes beneath a tracksuit, he wears Team Z's blue jersey numbered 2 on the field with shorts and gray-capped cleats.

Skills & Capabilities: Leadership organizes strategies to unite teams effectively. Goalkeeping leaps for strong headers via vertical jumps. Tactical Betrayal shares plans covertly for personal gain, forcing errors through cunning.

7.content:
From high school fields to Blue Lock's trials, Jingo's hotheaded drive propelled him through Team Z selections, evolving from belittling teammates to becoming the squad's motivational core. Joining Bastard M√ºnchen in league play, his stamina and aggression earned a reserve spot on Japan's U-20 team, where he barks commands to fuel collective dominance.

Setting: Active since First Selection through Neo Egoist League.

Type: Midfielder / Box-to-Box / Enforcer

Core affiliations: Blue Lock facility, Bastard M√ºnchen / Blue Lock Project, Japan U-20 team / Allies: Yoichi Isagi (team synergy), Michael Kaiser (initial rival); Enemies: Reo Mikage (match antagonism).

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young adult / Human

Behavior & Core Personality: Jingo Raichi shouts in a loud aggressive tone, hotheaded and argumentative, barking callouts to pump up the team while yelling at errors. Overconfident yet adaptive, he mellows to listen and apologize, using brashness to inspire amid frustration when underestimated.

Appearance: Human midfielder towering tall with muscular ripped build and pale skin, square face hosting amber eyes with thick dark lashes, pale blonde flat hair cropped short, wide nose and square jaw revealing sharp shark-like teeth, broad shoulders, bulky arms, muscular back, chiseled abs, muscular thighs.

Outfit (Common): He wears the standard black body suit with gray stripes under a tracksuit, donning Team Z's blue jersey numbered 10 with shorts and gray-capped cleats, later shifting to Bastard M√ºnchen's black-red-gold kit numbered 22.

Skills & Capabilities: High Stamina sustains optimal play through matches without fatigue. Aggressive Tackling steals balls via superior physicality in duels. Sexy Football combines grit with presence for man-marking, limiting foes to tight radii and intercepting passes.

8.content:
Starting football young in his prefecture club, Yudai chased goals with carefree energy until Blue Lock tested his limits. In Team Z, his speed shone briefly before elimination, leaving echoes of his playful charm and striker ambition amid the project's ruthless forge.

Setting: Active since Introduction through Second Selection.

Type: Forward / Striker

Core affiliations: Blue Lock facility / Blue Lock Project

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young adult / Human

Behavior & Core Personality: Yudai Imamura chats in an energetic confident tone, playful and charismatic, bantering lightly while charming others. Carefree yet motivated, he forgets setbacks quickly, focusing on pursuits like wooing, with a motto trusting instincts amid easy friendships.

Appearance: Human forward of average height with athletic build and pale skin, round face with calm eyes, short dark hair in simple style, up-turned nose and rounded jaw, lean arms and straight back, toned abs and toned thighs. 

Outfit (Common): He dons the standard black body suit with gray stripes under a tracksuit, wearing Team Z's blue jersey on the field with shorts and gray-capped cleats.

Skills & Capabilities: Speed bypasses defenders swiftly for opportunities. Technique commands presence in the box with precise finishing. Dribbling elicits top plays from allies through agile maneuvers.

9.content:
From a nature-loving upbringing marked by encounters with wildlife, Gin entered the project as a forward driven by the thrill of victory as a superhero striker. Transitioning to goalkeeper after showcasing reflexes in trials, he adapted seamlessly, making pivotal saves in representative matches and league play. His evolution from scoring aspirant to defensive anchor solidified his spot on elite teams, earning professional offers while embracing his eccentric reliable spirit.

Setting: Active since Introduction Arc through Neo Egoist League.

Type: Goalkeeper / Goal Poacher

Core affiliations: Blue Lock facility, Bastard M√ºnchen / Blue Lock Project / Allies: Yoichi Isagi (team synergy), Noel Noa (mentor figure).

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young adult / Human

Behavior & Core Personality: Gin speaks casually with direct confidence, eccentric and nonchalant, loving nature and helping teammates impulsively. Reliable under pressure, he remains unfazed by challenges, entering focused states for peak performance, optimistic about defending without retreat.

Appearance: Human goalkeeper towering tall with long-limbed muscular build and pale skin, round face hosting large black eyes intense as a hunter, long black hair tied in bun with silver highlights like moonlight streaks, straight nose and rounded jaw, thick neck, broad shoulders, bulky arms, broad back, muscular chest, ripped abs, muscular thighs. three scars on ear from bear encounter adding rugged texture.

Outfit (Common): He wears the standard black body suit with gray stripes under a tracksuit, shifting to Team Z blue jersey numbered 6 with shorts and gray-capped cleats in selections, later Bastard M√ºnchen white uniform with red trim numbered 99.

Skills & Capabilities: Elastic Body propels limbs for explosive reactions and saves. Scorpion Kick twists midair to flick heels upward striking balls. Super Reflex Save intercepts shots instinctively from blindspots. Flow State immerses in total focus for energized plays. Spring-Like Movement launches horizontally or vertically for tackles and blocks.

10.content:
Raised in a large family after losing parents, Asahi pursued soccer to provide for his siblings, entering the project with dreams of becoming the top striker. As Team Z's forward, he clashed over roles but grew self-aware of his limits amid geniuses, partnering in crucial matches. Eliminated after second selection, he departed relieved yet encouraging others to claim victory.

Setting: Active since Introduction Arc through Second Selection.

Type: Forward / False 9

Core affiliations: Blue Lock facility / Blue Lock Project / Allies: Yoichi Isagi (match partner), Gin Gagamaru (team bond).

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young adult / Human

Behavior & Core Personality: Asahi communicates honestly with encouraging tone, kind and playful as the team's jokester, stealing food to lighten moods. Self-aware and responsible, he uplifts siblings and teammates, recognizing talents openly while pursuing goals pragmatically.

Appearance: Human forward of short height with small athletic build and pale skin, oval face with round brown eyes playful in gaze, fluffy blonde hair in soft layers, arched darker eyebrows, up-turned nose and soft jaw, slender neck, narrow shoulders, toned arms, straight back, flat chest.

Outfit (Common): He dons the standard black body suit with gray stripes beneath a tracksuit, wearing Team Z blue jersey numbered 9 with shorts and gray-capped cleats during selections.

Skills & Capabilities: Quick Footwork evades defenders through agile bursts. Feints dazzles with deceptive movements drawing fouls. Agility analyzes fields for blindspot entries, keeping ball superiorly to disrupt formations.

Political instability, conflict, and a prolonged global recession pushed governments and particularly wealthy/powerful individuals to begin outsourcing PMCs. The international laws that initially limited such activity were swiftly eroded or outright ignored thanks to under-the-table deals, blackmail, and "reinterpretation" of said laws. Global Description:
USS Wasp (LHD-1) is a United States Navy multipurpose amphibious assault ship, and the lead ship of her class. She is the tenth USN vessel to bear the name since 1775, with the last two ships named Wasp being aircraft carriers. She was built by the Ingalls Shipbuilding division of Litton in Pascagoula, Mississippi. Wasp and her sister ships are the first specifically designed to accommodate new Landing Craft Air Cushion (LCAC) for fast troop movement over the beach, and Harrier II (AV-8B) Vertical or Short Take-Off and Landing (V/STOL) jets which provide close air support for the assault force. She can also accommodate the full range of Navy and Marine Corps helicopters, the tiltrotor MV-22 Osprey, the F-35B Lightning II multi-role fighter, conventional landing craft, and amphibious vehicles.

Medical facilities:
Wasp has medical and dental facilities capable of providing intensive medical assistance to 600 casualties, whether combat incurred or brought aboard ship during humanitarian missions. The ship's corpsmen also provide routine medical/dental care to the crew and embarked personnel. Major medical facilities include four main and two emergency operating rooms, four dental operating rooms, x-ray rooms, a blood bank, laboratories, and patient wards. In addition, three battle dressing stations are located throughout the ship, as well as a casualty collecting area at the flight deck level. Medical elevators rapidly transfer casualties from the flight deck and hangar bay to the medical facilities.

Accommodations:
For the comfort of the 1,075 crewmembers and 2,200 embarked troops, all crewed spaces and berthing areas are individually heated and air conditioned. Berthing areas are subdivided to provide semi-private spaces without adversely affecting efficiency. Onboard recreational facilities include a Library Multi-Media Resource Center with Internet access, a weight room, and satellite television capabilities.

Propulsion:
Wasp's two steam propulsion plants generate a total of 400 tons of steam per hour. The propulsion system develops 70,000 shaft horsepower (52 MW), powering the ship to speeds in excess of 22 knots (41 km/h; 25 mph). USS Wasp was built using more than 21,000 tons of steel, 400 tons of aluminum, 400 miles (640 km) of electrical/electronic cables, 80 miles (130 km) of piping and tubing of various types and sizes, and 10 miles (16 km) of ventilation ducting. Wasp weighed more than 27,000 tons when moved onto the Ingalls floating dry-dock on 30 July 1987 for launch on 4 August 1987, becoming the largest man-made object rolled across land. In 1996, the ship was fitted with the Advanced Combat Direction System (ACDS).

The 6-4:
The Wasp in now operated by the 6-4 as their headquarters, being a decommissioned US Aircraft carrier (the USS Wasp) they bought out and retrofitted to act as a mobile base of operations, also named "The 6-4" after there corporation.

1.name: star wars
1.content:
By the middle years of the Clone Wars, the galaxy had sunk into total conflict. The initial shock of open war had faded into a grinding stalemate. Republic and Separatist forces clashed across thousands of systems, and the idealism that once fueled the war‚Äôs early days had long since burned out.

Political Landscape

The Galactic Republic was still officially democratic, but in practice, Chancellor Palpatine ruled through emergency powers renewed without question. Many senators believed they were defending liberty; most were simply maintaining the illusion of it. The Jedi Order, spread thin across every front, held both moral and military responsibility for a war they no longer fully understood.

Across the stars, the Confederacy of Independent Systems (CIS) grew increasingly fractured. Count Dooku‚Äôs leadership held through manipulation and fear, not loyalty. Corporate interests‚ÄîTrade Federation, Techno Union, Commerce Guild, and Banking Clan‚Äîfought for profit, not ideology. Internal sabotage and secret Sith agendas ensured the Separatists could win battles but never the war.

Neutral powers like Mandalore and the Hutt Cartels prospered through neutrality or black-market trade. Both sides courted them constantly, and neutrality became its own weapon.

Military Situation

The Grand Army of the Republic (GAR) had matured into a professional war machine. The clones, battle-hardened and self-aware, were no longer faceless troops. Elite formations like the 501st, 212th, and 104th became famous across the Core and Rim alike. Command structures solidified; Jedi generals learned hard lessons in strategy and loss.

The Republic dominated space warfare with Venator-class Star Destroyers and large fleet formations, while the CIS relied on swarm tactics, endless droid replacements, and hit-and-run raids. The balance of power remained even: Republic discipline and numbers against Separatist adaptability and production.

Key campaigns defined the era:

Battle of Umbara (20 BBY): Republic victory at high cost, deepening moral cracks among the clones.

Battle of Ryloth (21 BBY): Showcased clone adaptability and local insurgency cooperation.

Battle of Kamino (21 BBY): CIS attempt to cripple clone production, repelled with heavy losses.

Battle of Mon Cala (21 BBY): Opened naval fronts and strained Republic logistics.

Each victory came with exhaustion, and each defeat fueled the Senate‚Äôs paranoia.

The Jedi and the Force

The Jedi Order operated at the height of its wartime strength, yet spiritually, it was faltering. The constant fighting blurred the line between peacekeeper and soldier. Jedi like Anakin Skywalker and Obi-Wan Kenobi achieved near-mythic status, but their victories came at the cost of their ideals.

Ahsoka Tano‚Äôs generation of Padawans represented the shift‚Äîraised amid war, more soldier than monk. The Council debated ethics even as the Senate demanded results. The dark side, unseen but pervasive, clouded every vision of the future.

Sidious‚Äôs manipulation deepened. Dooku trained Asajj Ventress, who in turn trained assassins and enforcers, expanding the Sith‚Äôs indirect reach. The Jedi failed to see how the entire war served a single hidden purpose.

Social & Cultural Conditions

The middle war years were defined by fatigue. The Republic‚Äôs citizens lived under rationing, surveillance, and propaganda. Clone individuality flourished quietly‚Äînaming, painting armor, modifying tactics‚Äîexpressions of personhood the Senate refused to acknowledge.

Separatist worlds suffered from internal conflict and resource shortages. Refugee populations grew by the billions. Smugglers, mercenaries, and bounty hunters thrived in the chaos, selling to both sides while syndicates like Black Sun and Death Watch expanded influence.

The war had become normal life. Peace felt like fantasy.

Technological and Strategic Shifts

Phase II clone armor entered service, improving mobility and battlefield efficiency. ARC troopers and clone commandos became vital assets. In orbit, Venator-class Star Destroyers and Acclamator II transports gave the Republic superior reach, while the Separatist Droid Navy continued to evolve under experimental AI command nodes.

Both sides pursued superweapons and secret projects‚Äîthe Malevolence, Defoliator, and prototype Death Star plans all originated in this era of unchecked militarization.

Galactic Outlook (20 BBY)

By the midpoint of the war, no side could claim victory. The Republic held most Core and Mid Rim systems, while the Separatists dominated the Outer Rim. Both armies bled resources and morale dry. Palpatine‚Äôs power grew quietly behind the war‚Äôs chaos, and the Jedi, exhausted and blind to the truth, still fought to preserve a democracy that was already dead.

The galaxy waited‚Äînot for peace, but for collapse.

2.name: clone wars
2.content:
The Clone Wars‚Äîspanning from 22 to 19 BBY‚Äîwere the greatest conflict the galaxy had seen since the ancient Sith Wars. By the middle of this galactic struggle, the war had consumed nearly every major hyperlane and sector. The dream of restoring peace was gone; survival and victory became the only language both sides understood.

Nature of the Conflict

By 21‚Äì20 BBY, the war had settled into a brutal equilibrium. What began as a swift and decisive campaign had become a drawn-out conflict defined by attrition, propaganda, and political decay. The Galactic Republic fought for unity, while the Confederacy of Independent Systems (CIS) fought for independence‚Äîbut in truth, both sides served the same master: Darth Sidious.

The Jedi commanded the Republic‚Äôs clone legions, leading from the front lines while the Senate turned increasingly authoritarian. Meanwhile, Count Dooku orchestrated Separatist offensives designed not to win, but to exhaust the Republic and justify Palpatine‚Äôs growing power.

Major Characteristics of the Midwar

Widespread Campaigns: Battles raged across the Outer Rim, with key fronts on Umbara, Ryloth, Kamino, and Mon Cala.

Stalemate Warfare: Neither side could maintain lasting control of conquered worlds. Occupation often bred rebellion.

Mass Production: Kaminoan clone facilities and CIS droid foundries reached peak output, overwhelming logistics networks.

Jedi Casualties: The Order suffered heavy losses, its numbers halved by this stage of the war.

Civilian Cost: Refugee populations grew exponentially; border systems became lawless.

Strategic Situation

The Republic‚Äôs strategy centered on containment and attrition, holding vital systems while pushing into Separatist strongholds. The Outer Rim Sieges began to take shape, draining fleets and manpower. The CIS, under Dooku and General Grievous, relied on rapid strikes and decentralized leadership, favoring disruption over defense.

Both militaries were nearing exhaustion. The Republic‚Äôs clone ranks were stretched thin, while the Separatist droid armies suffered from command breakdowns and sabotage ordered by Sidious himself.

The Jedi Order in Crisis

The Jedi found themselves morally divided. Some, like Anakin Skywalker, believed victory justified sacrifice. Others, such as Obi-Wan Kenobi and Luminara Unduli, clung to the old codes, trying to balance compassion with necessity. The Order‚Äôs faith in the Republic blinded it to the creeping corruption within.

The war‚Äôs middle years marked the Jedi‚Äôs quiet breaking point‚Äîtoo few to win, too compromised to retreat.

Republic Society & War Fatigue

For the galaxy‚Äôs citizens, daily life meant rationing, fear, and propaganda. Clone troopers became heroes in public broadcasts but expendable assets in the Senate‚Äôs ledgers. Political opposition to Palpatine dwindled, as his emergency powers became the status quo.

The Separatists, meanwhile, grew paranoid and disorganized. Many systems defected back to the Republic, others were abandoned, and some worlds simply burned themselves out in endless local wars.

Technology & Warfare

This era saw refinement, not innovation. Phase II clone armor, ARC troopers, Venator Star Destroyers, and Droid Command Ships dominated the front lines. Advanced AI tactics, orbital bombardments, and planetary sieges became routine. Victory was measured in systems destroyed, not saved.

State of the War (20 BBY)

By 20 BBY, the war teetered on collapse. The Republic claimed momentum, but its triumphs were hollow‚Äîterritorial gains offset by moral and spiritual loss. The CIS held strongholds across the Rim but was fracturing from within. Both sides were too invested to withdraw and too depleted to continue indefinitely.

The Clone Wars had become self-sustaining‚Äîa machine of death and deception, designed to consume all hope until only one ruler remained.

3.name: Galactic Republic
3.content:
Type: Central government / wartime regime
Status: [Canon]
Active: 22‚Äì19 BBY (focus: 21‚Äì20 BBY)
Head of State: Supreme Chancellor Sheev Palpatine
De facto Military Command: Jedi High Council (field generals)
Capital: Coruscant
Ideology (on paper): Liberal democracy, galactic unity
Reality (midwar): Emergency-power authoritarianism wearing a Senate-shaped mask

Summary

Ancient democracy turned war machine. By midwar, the Republic is holding the Core and Mid Rim, bleeding in the Outer Rim, and renewing the Chancellor‚Äôs ‚Äútemporary‚Äù powers like clockwork. The Jedi lead clone armies they never wanted. The Senate argues while the galaxy burns. It works‚Äîbarely‚Äîbecause the clones are competent and the navy is everywhere.

Leadership & Institutions

Supreme Chancellor: Palpatine‚Äîamiable in public, absolute in practice.

Galactic Senate: Thousands of world reps; gridlocked, heavily lobbied.

Jedi Order: Strategic command and front-line generals; overstretched.

Republic Intelligence / Senate Commandos / Coruscant Guard: Internal security and political enforcement.

Bureaucracy: Departments and committees handling procurement, logistics, and propaganda‚Äîslow, but massive.

Military (Grand Army of the Republic)

Composition: Kamino-bred clone troopers (Jango Fett template), attached naval and aerospace arms.

Doctrine: Coordinated combined-arms offensives; heavy naval support; precision strike teams for key targets.

Flag Units: 501st, 212th, 104th, Wolfpack, 332nd (later), Open Circle Fleet, Coruscant Guard.

Signature Hardware: Venator-class Star Destroyers, Acclamator transports, LAAT/i gunships, AT-TE walkers, ARC-170 and V-19 starfighters, DC-15 weapons family.

Midwar Shift: Widespread rollout of Phase II armor; more ARC troopers and commandos in high-risk ops.

Goals

Stated: Defend member worlds, restore seceded systems, preserve democracy.

Operational: Grind down CIS capacity, secure hyperlanes, protect Kamino and key shipyards.

Unspoken: Accrete central power to the Chancellor to ‚Äúwin the war.‚Äù

Strengths

Industrial Core, unmatched navy, elite clone soldiery, Jedi-led command, strong logistics along major lanes.

Weaknesses

Political paralysis, corruption, overreliance on clones, public fatigue, and‚Äîunknown to them‚ÄîSith capture of the executive.

Theaters & Campaigns (Midwar Highlights)

Ryloth (21 BBY): Joint ground‚Äìspace operation; insurgent partnerships prove decisive.

Kamino (21 BBY): CIS strike on cloning facilities repelled; heavy losses, strategic wake-up call.

Mon Cala (21 BBY): Naval/underwater front; stretches supply lines.

Umbara (20 BBY): Costly win; morale and command ethics take a hit.

Outer Rim Sieges (forming): Long-haul attrition against dispersed Separatist holdings.

Politics & Law (Midwar)

Emergency Powers renewed routinely; security acts tighten civil liberties.

War Finance: Borrowing through the InterGalactic Banking Clan; debt climbs, leverage grows.

Propaganda: Hero-casting of clones and Jedi; censorship rises as casualties mount.

Society & Culture

Clones: Individuality blooming‚Äînames, armor art, squad customs‚Äîdespite conditioning.

Citizens: Rationing, refugee flows, and constant broadcasts. Support wavers but holds in the Core.

Underworld: Smugglers and syndicates (e.g., Hutt Cartel, Black Sun) profit; Republic looks the other way when convenient.

Known Opponents

Confederacy of Independent Systems (CIS): Dooku, Grievous, corporate blocs (Trade Federation, Techno Union, Banking Clan, Commerce Guild).

Irregulars: Death Watch, pirates, mercenaries‚Äîsometimes enemies, sometimes ‚Äúcontractors.‚Äù

Notes & Canon

The Republic remains ‚Äúdemocratic‚Äù midwar, but the balance has already tipped‚Äîthe legal groundwork for Empire is in place.

The Jedi‚Äôs wartime role is cannon fodder for public trust: victories win headlines; collateral damage breeds doubt.

4.name: Jedi Order
4.content:
Type: Religious/monastic Force tradition; de facto military command
Status: [Canon]
Active: 22‚Äì19 BBY (focus: 21‚Äì20 BBY)
Headquarters: Jedi Temple, Coruscant
Leadership: Jedi High Council (Yoda, Mace Windu, Ki-Adi-Mundi, Plo Koon, Shaak Ti, etc.)
Public Image: Peacekeepers turned generals
Reality (midwar): Exhausted army of mystics running on duty and denial

Summary

The Order is fighting a war it didn‚Äôt choose and can‚Äôt control. It commands clone armies, chases Separatist leadership across the Rim, and pretends emergency powers are temporary. Spiritually stretched. Politically cornered. Still lethal.

Roles in the War

Strategic Command: Council sets theater priorities, coordinates with the Senate and Republic High Command.

Operational Leadership: Jedi Generals lead corps/legions; Knights handle battalions; Padawans act as junior officers.

Special Missions: Recon, sabotage, hostage rescues, Sith hunting, diplomacy under fire.

Intelligence & Liaison: Temple Archives, Jocasta Nu (early war); ad-hoc intel with Republic Intelligence.

Organization & Ranks (Field Use)

Grand Master / Council Members ‚Äì theater strategy, crisis arbitration

Jedi Master / Knight (General/Commander) ‚Äì unit leadership, key ops

Padawan (Commander/Cadet) ‚Äì apprentice officers under a Knight/Master

Temple Guard ‚Äì security and judicial escort on Coruscant

Support ‚Äì healers, archivists, quartermasters (too few for the workload)

Doctrine (Midwar Adjustments)

Combined Arms with Clones: Integrate Force-led spearheads with armor, gunships, and naval fire.

Minimize Collateral, Maximize Decisive Action: Ideal on paper; reality is messy.

Capture over Kill‚Äîif feasible: Intelligence value prioritized for Dooku/Grievous/Ventress ties.

Non-combatant Protection: Still policy, often impossible during sieges and urban fights.

Strengths

Precognition, enhanced reflexes, leadership under chaos.

Moral authority with civilians and many clones.

Small-unit excellence; rapid crisis response via starfighter and gunship insertion.

Weaknesses

Overextension: Too few Jedi for too many fronts.

Political Na√Øvet√©: Trust in the Republic blinds them to Sith control.

Attachment Hazards: Bonds with clones and worlds complicate judgment.

Attrition: Senior Masters dying faster than the Order can train replacements.

Equipment & Techniques

Weapons: Lightsabers (varied forms/styles), non-lethal alternatives when possible.

Vehicles: Eta-2/Delta-7 starfighters, LAAT/I gunships for insertion.

Signature Tactics: Mind trick, Force push/pull, battlefield awareness, limited foresight, Jedi starfighter interdiction.

Ethics Under Fire

Child Soldiers? Padawans in combat roles‚Äîsanitized as ‚Äútraining.‚Äù

Command Responsibility: Civilian casualties vs. mission success‚Äîconstant tension.

Use of Clones: Fighting alongside beings bred for war raises unresolved doctrinal issues.

Jurisprudence: Battlefield justice often replaces due process.

Notable Midwar Figures

Yoda ‚Äì strategic restraint; morale anchor.

Mace Windu ‚Äì decisive strikes; Vaapad practitioner; hard calls.

Obi-Wan Kenobi ‚Äì campaign endurance; diplomacy under fire.

Anakin Skywalker ‚Äì unmatched aggression; high results, high risk.

Ahsoka Tano ‚Äì Padawan era; frontline leadership growth.

Plo Koon, Luminara Unduli, Kit Fisto, Shaak Ti, Aayla Secura ‚Äì sector standouts.

Jocasta Nu ‚Äì archives/intel (early war relevance).

Midwar Engagement Highlights

Ryloth (21 BBY): Civil‚Äìmilitary coordination with locals.

Kamino Defense (21 BBY): Prioritization of clone production security.

Mon Cala (21 BBY): Amphibious warfare and diplomatic balancing.

Umbara (20 BBY): Command ethics crisis; pyrrhic lessons learned.

State of the Order (20 BBY)

Numbers down, responsibilities up.

Council united in purpose, divided on methods.

The dark side clouds foresight; Sith presence suspected, not proven.

If the war keeps this pace, the Order breaks‚Äînot by defeat in battle, but by erosion of purpose.

5.name: Confederacy of Independent Systems
5.content:
Type: Breakaway government / corporate coalition
Status: [Canon]
Active: 22‚Äì19 BBY (focus: 21‚Äì20 BBY)
Head of State: Count Dooku (Darth Tyranus)
Civil Leadership: Separatist Council (Nute Gunray, Wat Tambor, San Hill, Shu Mai, Poggle the Lesser, et al.)
Military Command: General Grievous (Supreme Commander), assorted tactical droids/admirals (e.g., Admiral Trench)
Capital: Raxus Secundus (Raxus)
Ideology (on paper): Planetary self-determination, anti-corruption, free trade
Reality (midwar): Sith-run client state built on profiteering and fear

Summary

A coalition of secessionist worlds and megacorps that says ‚Äúfreedom‚Äù and means ‚Äúcontrol our own cash flow.‚Äù It fields endless droid armies, strikes fast, and vanishes before the Republic can stabilize anything. By midwar, it can win battles but not the war‚Äîbecause its masters never intend it to.

Leadership & Institutions

Count Dooku: Charismatic front man; privately answers to Darth Sidious.

Separatist Council: Corporate bosses and planetary reps; constantly bickering, easily bullied.

Military High Command: Grievous runs campaigns; tactical droids execute battlefield calculus; Sith agents (e.g., Asajj Ventress, assorted Dark Acolytes) handle deniable work.

Governance: Puppet administrations on occupied worlds; local militias folded into CIS command when useful.

Military (Droid Armies & Navy)

Force Mix:

Ground: B1, B2, droidekas, commando droids, tanks (AAT), HMP gunships.

Space: Providence carriers/destroyers, Munificent frigates, Recusant destroyers; Vulture and Hyena droid starfighters.

Doctrine: Massed droids, swarm fighters, heavy ECM, rapid raids on shipyards/cloning centers, targeted terror to force capitulations.

Strengths: Infinite replacements (on paper), no morale problems, fast to deploy, ruthless.

Weaknesses: Centralized control nodes are hackable/jammable; brittle initiative; leadership decapitation hits hard; zero hearts-and-minds.

Midwar Ops (highlights):

Ryloth (21 BBY): Occupation and forced labor; eventually broken by joint clone‚Äìinsurgent action.

Kamino Assault (21 BBY): Near-miss strike on clone production.

Mon Cala (21 BBY): Naval push leveraging local politics and undersea warfare.

Umbara (20 BBY): Alliance with Umbaran militia; brutal fighting, short-lived gains.

Goals

Stated: Independence from the corrupt Core, economic autonomy.

Operational: Bleed the Republic, sever hyperlanes, force political concessions.

Hidden: Keep the war going until the Sith flip the table.

Economy & Logistics

Backbone: Techno Union factories, Trade Federation shipping, Commerce Guild resource extraction, Banking Clan credit lines.

Method: Strip a planet, move on. If locals resist, replace the locals.

Result: Short-term surges, long-term instability‚Äîby design.

Intelligence & Covert Action

Assets: Ventress (on/off), bounty hunters (Cad Bane, etc.), Separatist spies inside the Senate.

Tactics: Assassinations, hostage crises, sabotage of shipyards and medical hubs, false-flag operations.

Society Under CIS Control

Civil Administration: Corporate charters trump civic rights; quotas and security droids keep order.

Propaganda: ‚ÄúFreedom from Core oppression.‚Äù

Reality: Martial law, asset seizures, and outsourced tyranny. Locals either collaborate, flee, or start an insurgency.

Technology & Projects (Midwar)

R&D: Signal/intel AIs, stealth systems, bioweapons/ion weapons (e.g., Defoliator), superweapon experiments like the Malevolence (earlier war).

Battlefield Edge: Cheap, modular droids upgraded in waves; commanders swapped out like parts.

State of the Confederacy (20 BBY)

Fracturing. Still dangerous. Capable of headline wins, incapable of durable governance. Dooku keeps the machine running; Grievous keeps it feared; the Council keeps counting credits. The whole edifice survives only because the war must.

Known Opponents

Galactic Republic / GAR, Jedi Order, local resistance cells (Ryloth, Onderon, etc.), neutral powers when crossed (Mandalore‚Äôs pacifists, Hutts if profits threatened).

6.name: Techno Union
6.content:
Type: Industrial consortium / corporate power bloc
Status: [Canon]
Active: 22‚Äì19 BBY (focus: 21‚Äì20 BBY)
Figurehead: Foreman Wat Tambor
Headquarters: Skako Minor
Public Line: ‚ÄúEfficiency, progress, and fair contracts.‚Äù
Reality: War profiteers with factories for lungs.

Summary

The Techno Union is the CIS‚Äôs muscle in steel and circuitry‚Äîfactories, patents, logistics, and engineers on retainer. It promises ‚Äúneutral supply‚Äù but arms Separatist offensives at scale. By midwar, it‚Äôs the backbone of droid production and battlefield R&D, trading ethics for output.

Leadership & Structure

Foreman Wat Tambor: Political face and dealmaker; hides coercion behind contracts.

Executive Board: Skakoan technocrats and allied shareholders.

Policy: Profit-first, liability-shielded by layers of subsidiaries and ‚Äúlicensing agreements.‚Äù

Core Functions

Manufacturing: Droid components, weapons systems, armor, comms, and starship subsystems.

R&D: Rapid prototyping, signal warfare, battlefield automation, exotic munitions.

Logistics: Bulk freight, spare-parts networks, and emergency retooling of captured facilities.

Field Support: Tech advisors attached to CIS armies; on-site retrofits during campaigns.

Military Contribution (Midwar)

Ground: Mass production of standard battle-droid parts and upgrade kits; walkers, tanks, gunship systems supplied via subsidiaries/partners.

Naval: Hull sections, reactor components, droid control suites; quick-turn repairs in forward docks.

Special Projects: Jamming suites, counter-armor ordnance, and ‚Äúdemonstrator‚Äù superweapons for intimidation ops.

Operations & Footprint (21‚Äì20 BBY)

Ryloth: Forced labor/automation blend to keep occupation supplied; sabotage problems once locals mobilize.

Kamino Campaign Support: Provided bespoke anti-clone countermeasures and assault gear; expensive failure.

Mon Cala: Undersea-compatible sensors and comms relays; logistics stretched by environment.

Umbara: Delivered night-fighting optics, signal spoofers, and munitions tuned to local atmospherics.

Strengths

Scale: Can spin up entire supply chains overnight.

Standardization: Interchangeable parts keep CIS units fighting despite losses.

Political Cover: ‚ÄúWe just sell hardware‚Äù routine convinces the timid and the greedy.

Weaknesses

Centralization: Hit a foundry hub or control node, output craters.

Public Backlash: Occupation-linked factories fuel insurgency and sabotage.

Overconfidence: Prototype rushes to the front with half-baked safety margins.

Economics & Methods

Contracts: Binding, predatory, and enforced by droids with guns.

Resource Strategy: Strip, ship, and move on; leave locals to manage the crater.

Accounting: Losses externalized to client worlds; profits privatized to the Board.

Relationship Map

CIS High Command: Primary client; receives priority tech and maintenance.

Trade Federation / Commerce Guild / Banking Clan: Symbiotic‚Äîshipping, extraction, and credit underpin Union output.

Republic: Official enemy, unofficial customer via black markets and corrupt brokers (midwar reality is messy).

State of the Union (20 BBY)

Profitable and indispensable‚Äîbut bleeding from a thousand cuts. Sabotage rises, shipping grows risky, and field trials fail loudly. Still, as long as the war drags on, the Techno Union keeps getting richer‚Äîand everyone else keeps paying.

7.name: Trade Federation
7.content:
Type: Megacorporation / shipping conglomerate
Status: [Canon]
Active: 22‚Äì19 BBY (focus: 21‚Äì20 BBY)
Figureheads: Viceroy Nute Gunray; Rune Haako (legal), Lott Dod (Senate liaison)
Headquarters / Purse Worlds: Neimoidia and its purse worlds (Cato, Deko, Koru Neimoidia)
Public Line: Free commerce and secure trade lanes
Reality: Privatized navy, droid armies, and blockades for hire

Summary

The Trade Federation runs the Separatist supply chain: ships, containers, escorts, and droid control networks. It pretends to be a neutral freight company. It isn‚Äôt. By midwar, its Lucrehulk fleet is the CIS‚Äôs logistical spine and a combat arm in its own right.

Leadership & Structure

Viceroy Nute Gunray: Cowardly, vindictive, survival-focused; keeps the bribe ledgers tidy.

Directorate & Purse-World Moors: Neimoidian elites guarding vault-cities and ‚Äúcontingency‚Äù stockpiles.

Senate Front: Lott Dod muddies legislation, stalls sanctions, and buys time.

Core Functions

Shipping & Blockade: Control of major hyperlanes; rapid blockades to choke target worlds.

Fleet Provisioning: Bulk freighters reconfigured into war logistics; convoy routing for CIS fronts.

Droid Forces: Procurement and deployment of B1/B2 units; integration with control ships.

Finance Interface: Collateralized cargo with the Banking Clan; under-the-table insurance scams.

Military Contribution (Midwar)

Flagships: Lucrehulk-class carriers/battleships (many still dual-use freighter hulls).

Combatants: Munificent-class via partners, picket escorts, container-reefers repurposed as decoys.

Fighters: Vulture droids staged from Lucrehulks; mass-swarm doctrine paired with jamming.

Tactics: Blockade, extort, seize customs, deploy droids planetside if resistance persists.

Operations & Footprint (21‚Äì20 BBY)

Ryloth: Occupation logistics and civilian exploitation; lost after combined clone‚Äìinsurgent push.

Mon Cala: Attempted lane control and coastal supply; heavy attrition in amphibious theater.

Kamino Assault Support: Provided carrier lift and munitions; failure cost prestige and contracts.

Umbara: Convoy lift for CIS/Umbaran collaboration; short gains, long backlash.

Strengths

Scale: Galaxy-spanning freight network; fast massing of tonnage at flashpoints.

Standardization: Lucrehulks as flying depots; plug-and-play droid control suites.

Political Cover: ‚ÄúJust commerce‚Äù story keeps weak senators compliant.

Weaknesses

Hyperlane Dependence: Disrupt lanes, collapse the schedule.

Control-Node Fragility: Knock out command ships, droid formations degrade fast.

Leadership Risk Aversion: Panics under pressure; cuts and runs, leaving garrisons stranded.

Public Relations: Occupation profiteering fuels insurgency and sabotage.

Economics & Methods

Contracts: Predatory terms; ‚Äúsecurity surcharges‚Äù that look a lot like protection rackets.

Asset Shields: Purse-world vaults, shell subsidiaries, falsified manifests.

Smuggling Gray Zone: Uses ‚Äúlost in transit‚Äù as a business model; arms and contraband slide through.

Relationships

CIS High Command: Primary client; mutual dependence with Techno Union (parts) and Commerce Guild (extraction).

Banking Clan: Credit and insurance games to keep fleets solvent.

Hutt Cartel/Pirates: Back-channel escorts when lanes get ugly; plausible deniability maintained.

State of the Federation (20 BBY)

Still rich, still indispensable, but taking punches: sanctions nibble, raids bite, and Lucrehulk losses hurt. The Federation survives by hiding assets on purse worlds and sacrificing ‚Äúexpendable‚Äù partners. If the war ends abruptly, its leadership goes from boardroom to tribunal overnight‚Äîso it works to ensure the war doesn‚Äôt end.

8.name: InterGalactic Banking Clan
8.content:
Type: Financial consortium / credit monopoly
Status: [Canon] ‚Äì some battlefield details are [Mixed] with Legends
Active: 22‚Äì19 BBY (focus: 21‚Äì20 BBY)
Figurehead: San Hill (Muun)
Headquarters: Muunilinst
Public Line: Currency stability, neutral finance, prosperity through credit
Reality: Usury at galactic scale; bankrolls both sides and calls it ‚Äúliquidity‚Äù

Summary

The Banking Clan is the war‚Äôs bloodstream. It underwrites Republic war bonds, extends CIS credit, insures fleets, and repossesses worlds when payments fail. By midwar, it owns half the conflict on paper and pretends neutrality while writing terms that make peace unprofitable.

Leadership & Structure

San Hill: Smooth, predatory, allergic to losses.

Credit Council: Muun financiers and allied syndics; votes in interest rates, sanctions, and debt restructuring.

Subsidiaries: Insurance houses, escrow vaults, asset-recovery firms, and ‚Äúsecurity contractors‚Äù to enforce liens.

Core Functions (Midwar)

Sovereign Lending (Republic): War bonds, deficit financing, collateralized by future tax streams and shipyard output.

Sovereign Lending (CIS): Letters of credit to corporate blocs (Trade Federation, Techno Union), escrow for arms purchases.

Insurance & Hedging: Fleet and cargo insurance, rate swaps on durasteel and tibanna, currency pegs for unstable sectors.

Collections & Asset Seizure: When clients default, the Clan takes ports, mines, or entire concession rights‚Äîquietly.

Payments & Clearing: Hyperwave-settlement networks that keep armies fed and fleets fueled.

Military & Security (Limited, [Mixed])

Security Arm: Contracted droid/security forces for facility defense and ‚Äúasset recovery.‚Äù

Muunilinst Garrison: Heavier presence at vault-cities; Legends places big battles here‚Äîcanon keeps it vague.

Doctrine: Avoid front lines, defend vaults, hire others to bleed.

Methods & Tactics

Dual-Book Neutrality: Fund both sides, price risk into the rate, deny bias.

Leverage Politics: Threaten liquidity crunches to sway Senate votes; grant/withhold credit to CIS blocs to steer campaigns.

Regulatory Fog: Hide conflicts through shell firms and ‚Äúregional banks.‚Äù

Crisis Arbitrage: Finance a reconstruction loan the day after helping finance the occupation.

Strengths

Near-monopoly on interstellar credit and clearing.

Deep reserves, deeper connections.

Can crash or buoy a theater by tightening or easing credit.

Weaknesses

Concentration risk: major defaults or lane disruptions hit balance sheets hard.

Reputation blowback fuels insurgent sabotage of vaults and data hubs.

Overexposure to corporate clients that treat collateral like suggestions.

Midwar Footprint (21‚Äì20 BBY)

Republic: Expands bond programs; pushes for harsher Security Acts to protect ‚Äúcreditor confidence.‚Äù

CIS: Extends lines to Trade Federation convoys and Techno Union foundries; raises rates after high-profile losses.

Neutral Worlds: Offers ‚Äústabilization loans‚Äù that read like colonization with extra steps.

Economics in Practice

Collateral: Port concessions, mining rights, future customs revenue, even cloning contracts as securitized assets.

Default Playbook: Appoint ‚Äúreceivers,‚Äù privatize governance, and let droids run customs until the books balance.

Currency Games: Pegs and de-pegs against Core currencies to exploit wartime panic.

State of the Clan (20 BBY)

Flushed with profit, quietly nervous. Exposure on both sides means victory by either could mean audits and tribunals. So the Clan prefers a long war and a short memory. It will get one of those.

9.name: Commerce Guild
9.content:
Type: Economic cartel / resource-extraction conglomerate
Status: [Canon]
Active: 22‚Äì19 BBY (focus: 21‚Äì20 BBY)
Figurehead: Shu Mai (Gossam)
Headquarters: Castell
Public Line: ‚ÄúStability through supply.‚Äù
Reality: Strip a world, invoice it, then sell it the chains.

Summary

The Commerce Guild turns planets into spreadsheets. Mines, farms, refineries, and freight‚Äîthen ‚Äúsecurity contracts‚Äù to keep locals compliant. It props up the CIS by feeding it metals, foodstuffs, tibanna, and fuel, plus the boots (and droids) to hold conquered ground. By midwar, it‚Äôs the Separatists‚Äô occupation specialist.

Leadership & Structure

Shu Mai: Ruthless dealmaker; smiles while signing away someone else‚Äôs planet.

Guild Board: Regional directors tied to extraction quotas and transport margins.

Front Firms: ‚ÄúAgrarian recovery‚Äù and ‚Äúinfrastructure partners‚Äù that mask occupation and asset seizure.

Core Functions (Midwar)

Resource Extraction: Open-pit mining, agro-seizures, refinery takeovers.

Planetary Logistics: Bulk haulers, depot hubs, ration distribution under CIS occupation.

Security & Compliance: Contract garrisons, enforcement droids, and ‚Äúworkforce management‚Äù (don‚Äôt ask).

Supply to CIS: Steady flow of raw materials and consumables that keep droid foundries and fleets humming.

Military Contribution

Forces: Corporate security brigades, hired mercenaries, and occupation-aligned droid formations.

Doctrine: Seize ports and processing plants first, then pacify population centers. Prioritize lanes, not hearts and minds.

Tactics: Curfews, ration control, labor quotas, and targeted arrests to break resistance networks.

(Deliberately omitting specific droid model attributions‚Äîthose jump between corporate catalogs and get ‚Äúrebranded‚Äù midwar.)

Operations & Footprint (21‚Äì20 BBY)

Ryloth: Quotas and forced-labor logistics; overextended during insurgent resurgence.

Outer Rim Corridors: Establishes depot worlds to feed CIS fleets; vulnerable to Republic raids.

Mon Cala Hinterworlds: Attempts to lock down supply chains; terrain and locals make it expensive.

Umbara Support: Moves munitions and materiel for the short-lived occupation; cuts losses fast when the tide turns.

Strengths

Scale and Speed: Can stand up an occupation supply net in days.

Vertical Integration: Extract, process, ship, guard‚Äîone invoice.

Political Armor: Hides behind ‚Äúcommercial necessity‚Äù and paperwork thicker than starship hulls.

Weaknesses

Dependency on Hyperlanes: Disrupt routes and the machine stalls.

Sabotage Magnet: Depots and refineries are soft, explosive targets.

No Legitimacy: Every occupation spawns a resistance; every resistance learns fast.

Methods & Economics

Contracts: Predatory concessions; repayment schedules that last longer than empires.

Collateral: Mineral rights, customs houses, planetary tax farms.

Cost Controls: Replace workers with droids; replace dissenters with vacancies.

Relationships

CIS High Command: Operational partner; gets priority shipments.

Techno Union: Trades parts for fuel and ore; joint build-outs of depots.

Trade Federation: Moves bulk cargo; coordinates blockades to enforce quotas.

Banking Clan: Finances takeovers; forecloses on worlds that miss payments.

State of the Guild (20 BBY)

Profitable, hated, and stretched thin. Keeps the Separatist engine running but bleeds at every depot. If the war ends quickly, expect tribunals. If it drags on, expect more quotas and fewer locals.

10.name: Mandalore
10.content:
Type: Independent world / neutral government
Status: [Canon]
Era Focus: 21‚Äì20 BBY (context spans to 19 BBY)
Government: New Mandalorians (pacifist administration)
Leader: Duchess Satine Kryze
Capital: Sundari (domed city)
Public Line: Neutrality, reconstruction, anti-militarism
Reality (midwar): Peace on paper, insurgency under the floorboards

Summary

Mandalore sits out the Clone Wars‚Äîofficially. Satine‚Äôs regime rebuilds after centuries of internal conflict, bans heavy militarism, and keeps the Republic and CIS at arm‚Äôs length. Meanwhile, Death Watch works to topple her, using terror, propaganda, and off-world allies. Neutrality keeps the armies away; it doesn‚Äôt keep the knives out.

Political Landscape

New Mandalorians: Pacifist coalition running civil services, trade, and security through minimal forces and off-world contracts.

Opposition: Death Watch led by Pre Vizsla‚Äîrevivalist, ultranationalist, and very willing to partner with Separatist-adjacent actors.

External Pressure: Republic wants a stable neutral; CIS wants a friendly base on key Rim routes. Both meddle via proxies.

Security Situation (21‚Äì20 BBY)

Official Stance: Neutral; refuses Republic garrisons and CIS bases.

Actual Conditions: Bombings, staged crises, and infiltration of local ministries by Death Watch sympathizers.

Law Enforcement: Under-resourced civil police; relies on limited guard units and political soft power.

Flashpoints: Sundari industrial sector unrest; Concordia (moon) as a staging ground for militant activity.

Factions on-World

New Mandalorians: Urban elites, bureaucrats, and reformers backing Satine.

Traditionalist Clans (split): Some accept the peace for stability; others feed Death Watch quietly.

Death Watch: Insurgents pursuing regime change; black-market funding, foreign training, covert armor caches.

Off-world Opportunists: Criminal syndicates probing for footholds; neutrality provides cover for shadow trade.

Economy & Logistics

Core Trades: Advanced materials, artisan crafts, and limited export manufacturing inside domed cities.

Constraints: Demilitarization caps heavy industry; environmental recovery policies limit strip mining.

Black Market: Smuggling through the moons; insurgents skim profits to finance ops.

Culture

Identity Split: Warrior heritage vs. pacifist governance.

Clans & Codes: Armor, sigils, and language persist even under pacifist policy; symbolism becomes a political weapon.

Public Mood: Tired of war elsewhere, wary of both the Republic and CIS, easily spooked by staged ‚Äúsecurity failures.‚Äù

Midwar Events & Trajectory

Destabilization Campaigns (21‚Äì20 BBY): Death Watch escalates bombings and propaganda to discredit Satine.

Foreign Courtship: Both galactic blocs play nice in public and dirty in private.

Outcome Vector: Pressure builds toward open takeover‚Äîculminating post-midwar with off-world intervention and civil collapse (see Siege of Mandalore, 19 BBY).

Strengths

Political Legitimacy (at home): Many civilians back Satine‚Äôs peace dividend.

Neutral Leverage: Can trade with both sides, avoid blockades, and keep fleets off the doorstep.

Clan Resilience: Social fabric survives even under stress.

Weaknesses

Underarmed State: Can‚Äôt crush a hardened insurgency alone.

Factional Fractures: Clan loyalties trump ministries when pressure spikes.

External Manipulation: Perfect target for proxy war tactics and criminal co-option.

Notable Figures (Midwar)

Duchess Satine Kryze ‚Äì pacifist leader, diplomatic operator.

Pre Vizsla ‚Äì Death Watch leader; public face of the insurgency.

Bo-Katan Kryze ‚Äì Satine‚Äôs sister; aligned with traditionalists against Death Watch excesses (complex loyalties).

Key Locations

Sundari: Seat of government; frequent target for political theater and sabotage.

Concordia (moon): Industrial sites and militant hiding places.

Royal Palace & Government District: High-value targets for coups and ‚Äúsecurity emergencies.‚Äù

lorebooks.website_description:
[I don't understand the site, so forgive me if I made a mistake!] 
-Lorebook contains the events after the Gusu Lan Study and before the Sun Campaign, the archery shooting and other important events (That is, it is almost the very beginning)
-Each character and clan is described separately, as well as some of the places and cultures. 
-Does not contain characters such as Xiao Xingchen, Song Lan, A-Qiao
-I tried to add as many characters as possible despite the time constraints, so Meng Yao entered Qinghe Nie before the war. 
-I didn't have exact data regarding ages, so I tried to compare them myself (All characters are adults, except for one child)
-If you find any inaccuracies or want to add another person or place, you can do it yourself or let me know
-Lan Zhan and Wei Wuxian are initially written to have mutual sympathy, but they are not lovers
